Plan name: UNSDCF - SOUTH AFRICA 2020-2025
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 4: Climate resilience and sustainably managed natural resources
Outcome: Outcome 4.1: By 2025, South Africa is on a just transition to a low-carbon society and vulnerable and marginalized communities adapt and are more resilient to adverse effects of climate change
Output: Output 4.1.2 Climate Change Adaptation Capacity of National, sub-national Government and communities strengthened for household food and nutrition, water and energy security
Sub-Output: 4.1.2.1 Support Climate Change Vulnerability Assessments (CCVA)/Resilience Analysis and the CC Adaptation Capacity Assessments for short and long-term risks to Agriculture, Human Health, Biodiversity and Ecosystems, Human Settlements, Water, Coastal and Marine sectors to strengthen resilience in vulnerable/marginalized communities
Agency abbreviations: FAO; IOM; UN-HABITAT; UNDP; UNEP; UNESCO; UNIDO; WHO
Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations; International Organization for Migration; United Nations Development Programme; United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation; United Nations Environment Programme; United Nations Human Settlement Programme; United Nations Industrial Development Organization; World Health Organization
Implementation partners: Agricultural Research Council; Council for Scientific and Industrial Research; South Africa, Department of Agriculture, Land Reform and Rural Development; South Africa, Department of Forestry, Fisheries and the Environment; South Africa, Department of Water and Sanitation; South African Local Government Association; The South African National Biodiversity Institute; Water Research Commission
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,3.9 By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.,3.d Strengthen the capacity of all countries, in particular developing countries, for early warning, risk reduction and management of national and global health risks.,11.b By 2020, substantially increase the number of cities and human settlements adopting and implementing integrated policies and plans towards inclusion, resource efficiency, mitigation and adaptation to climate change, resilience to disasters, and develop and implement, in line with the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction 2015-2030, holistic disaster risk management at all levels.,13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,14.2 By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans.,15.3 By 2030, combat desertification, restore degraded land and soil, including land affected by desertification, drought and floods, and strive to achieve a land degradation-neutral world.

Contributing partners: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

Human rights marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 2 OUTPUT 4.2: Normative frameworks, institutions and systems strengthened for conservation, sustainable use and equitable benefit sharing from the use of biodiversity and natural resources to ensure environmental sustainability for development.
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2020 Narrative: FAO supported the development of a national Web-based irrigation information system in Ethiopia. FAO worked with the relevant ministries to develop an operational Web-based IMISET to be deployed in the MoA server. The development of IMISET was preceded by a number of activities, including the determination of national irrigation indicators, the identification of the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders in data management, and the development of a methodology for data collection and analysis. Output 2 concerned the capacity-building of government staff in the use of IMISET and in irrigation water management. A total of 428 experts received training in data collection and entry in IMISET, and in IMISET algorithm and computation of indicators, while 238 federal and regional experts were trained in improved water management. Guidelines for data collection and entry in IMISET were prepared, and equipment provided for these activities and for improved farm water management practices. The final output regarded the collection of irrigation data and their entry in IMISET. This output was partially achieved. Irrigation data were collected from 158 irrigation schemes (against an envisaged target of 125) in five regions, but the data were not entered in IMISET as a result of challenges face by MoA in creating user accounts. When fully operational, IMISET will enable the Government to monitor the performance and status of irrigation systems, alert decision-makers and other relevant actors to take appropriate measures for low-performing and non-functional irrigation systems, establish a benchmark for research to improve irrigation performance, assess the contribution of irrigated agriculture to Gross Domestic Product, and estimate the number of permanent and temporary jobs created in the irrigation subsector.
2021 Narrative: FAO supported the development of a national Web-based irrigation information system in Ethiopia. FAO worked with the relevant ministries to develop an operational Web-based IMISET to be deployed in the MoA server. The development of IMISET was preceded by a number of activities, including the determination of national irrigation indicators, the identification of the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders in data management, and the development of a methodology for data collection and analysis. Output 2 concerned the capacity-building of government staff in the use of IMISET and in irrigation water management. A total of 428 experts received training in data collection and entry in IMISET, and in IMISET algorithm and computation of indicators, while 238 federal and regional experts were trained in improved water management. Guidelines for data collection and entry in IMISET were prepared, and equipment provided for these activities and for improved farm water management practices. The final output regarded the collection of irrigation data and their entry in IMISET. This output was partially achieved. Irrigation data were collected from 158 irrigation schemes (against an envisaged target of 125) in five regions, but the data were not entered in IMISET as a result of challenges face by MoA in creating user accounts. When fully operational, IMISET will enable the Government to monitor the performance and status of irrigation systems, alert decision-makers and other relevant actors to take appropriate measures for low-performing and non-functional irrigation systems, establish a benchmark for research to improve irrigation performance, assess the contribution of irrigated agriculture to Gross Domestic Product, and estimate the number of permanent and temporary jobs created in the irrigation subsector.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Strategic priority: Support inclusive economic growth and transformation
Outcome: Outcome 1: Inclusive, Resilient, Sustainable Economic Growth and Transformation
Output: Strengthened institutional and stakeholder capacities and regulatory frameworks for integrating climate change, environmental considerations and economic diversification, including natural resources management, food systems, value chains, enhanced trade, the blue, green and circular economy, private sector development, digitalization, decent employment and livelihoods.

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: FAO Technical Cooperation Programme; Swedish International Development Agency
Implementation partners: Environmental Protection Agency; Forestry Commission; Ghana Coalition of CSOs; Ghana Ministries of fisheries and aquaculture development; Ghana Ministry forÔøΩEnvironment, Science, Technology and Innovation; Ghana Ministry of Education; Ghana Ministry of Finance; Ghana Ministry of Food & Agriculture; Ghana Ministry of Local Government, Decentralisation and Rural Development; Ghana Ministry of trade and industry; Ghana National Development Planning Commission
SDG Targets: 1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

Focal users: Benjamin Adjei; Henrietta Appiah; Jefferson Attipoe
2023 Narrative: Local women in Ghana's savannah ecological zone have been trained of harvesting grass sustainably, produce the grass into briquettes and market their surplus for commercial sale.This initiative aims to capitalize on the potential of the region's grasses, helping reduce fire risk and forest degradation while contributing to ecological, economic and social goals.
2024 Narrative: FAO intervention in Norhtern Ghana enhanced capacity of soyabean producers to adopt sustainable production practices and the application of climate-smart agricultural techniques. Beneficiary farmers achieved an 87% increase in crop yield, raising productivity from 0.8 t/ha to 1.5 t/ha in targeted areas.

Outcome: Outcome 1.1 - Economic Growth & Employment

Sub-Output: 1.1.3.36 - To use off-grid box technology to provide energy and clean water to micro and small enterprises in remote rural areas
Description: The off-grid box technology project aims to provide energy and clean water to micro and small enterprises in remote rural areas that are not served by the national grid and clean and safe water not available. This is expected to have a multiplier effects in-terms of increase business activities, employment generation and save women from walking long distances to fetch water.
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2022-2026
Strategic priority: STRATEGIC PRIORITY AREA¬† 3: CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABLE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES
Outcome: Outcome 3: By 2026, more people, especially the most vulnerable, are resilient to climate change and disasters, and benefit from more sustainable management of environment and natural resources and resilient infrastructures and human settlements, with positive effects on national GDP.
Output: Output 3.2: Government institutions have stronger capacities for evidence-based (including gender analysis) decision making, accountability, and effective coordination for disasters and climate resilience, resilient infrastructures and the sustainable management of environment and natural resources ;
Sub-Output: Establishment of a Center of Excellence in Underwater Cultural Heritage Protection for Mozambique/Africa
Description: In light of the efforts to achieve the SDGs and the UN Decade of Ocean Science, this project shall enhance the sustainable protection and management of underwater cultural heritage by enhancing human and institutional capacities in Mozambique. The project will also support the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development (2021-2030), which includes the protection of the cultural heritage of the oceans. Finally, the project will also contribute to the African Union 2063 Agenda, and notably its Aspiration 5.  on Africa with strong cultural identify, common heritage, values and ethics.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: Mozambique Ministry of Culture; Universidade Eduardo Mondlane
SDG Targets: 4.7 By 2030, ensure that all learners acquire the knowledge and skills needed to promote sustainable development, including, among others, through education for sustainable development and sustainable lifestyles, human rights, gender equality, promotion of a culture of peace and nonviolence, global citizenship and appreciation of cultural diversity and of culture's contribution to sustainable development.,11.4 Strengthen efforts to protect and safeguard the world's cultural and natural heritage.
SDG Goals: 4 Quality Education; 11 Sustainable Cities and Communities
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Convening/Partnerships/Knowledge Sharing; Direct Support/ Service Delivery
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2022 Narrative: Delay to start the project due to political opposition forces around the ratification of the 2001 Convention. Ongoing advocacy with Government institutions and key stakeholders to ensure consensus and the success of the project implementation.
2023 Narrative: Underwater Cultural HeritageUNESCO is cooperating with the Ocean Decade Heritage Network (ODHN), which was established in 2019 with the aim of raising awareness of the UN Ocean Decade (2021-2030) within the cultural heritage community and coordinating the community's response to improve the integration of archaeology and cultural heritage management into marine science. Through Establishment of a Center of Excellence in Underwater Cultural Heritage Protection and Research for Mozambique project efforts are being undertaken to facilitate contact and communication between archaeologists, cultural heritage specialists, marine scientists, and relevant stakeholders, and to ensure that archaeologists and cultural heritage specialists, individually and through their own institutions and networks, are able to engage constructively in marine science under the auspices of the Decade, and to make the most of the opportunity that the Decade presents in supporting interdisciplinary marine research.Key achievement and results Technical and financial contract has been given to the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences to support the functionality of CAIRIM, Island of Mozambique and funds disbursed, in addition UNESCO UCH project assistant is based in Island of Mozambique central conditions for operationalizing and accelerating the project.Conducted workshops in cooperation with Slave Wrecks Project of the Smithsonian with focus on conservation principles, management and project planning, UCH access and museums through the setting up of a Maritime exhibition. As a result, 4 (2 female) CAIRIM employees strengthened their capacity to operationalize and manage museum, laboratory, tourism and architecture activities.Rehabilitation Project for establishment of the laboratory concluded and underway for local authorities‚Äô approval. A fundamental condition for the creation of a permanent exhibition of national shipwrecks, including the conservation of artifacts by a competent national team.Strategic actions for 2024 Organize the Regional and national Training on Underwater Cultural Heritage Management in the Island of Mozambique.Establishment of the Underwater Archaeological Laboratory, Museums exhibition, Tourism Trails and Dive.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (2025-2030)
Strategic priority: Food Systems, Natural Resource Management and Climate Change
Outcome: People in Sierra Leone, especially the most vulnerable, are food and nutrition secure, benefit from effective natural resource management, are resilient to the effects of climate change, and equipped to prevent and respond to disasters.
Output: Government and community stakeholders ensure development and enforcement of laws and policies, monitoring, and management systems, to effectively manage waste and protect natural resources and valuable ecosystems.
Sub-Output: Eartham established for good water management and irrigaion
Implementation partners: Sierra Leone Ministry of AgricultureForetry and Food Security
SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,1.2 By 2030, reduce at least by half the proportion of men, women and children of all ages living in poverty in all its dimensions according to national definitions.,1.3 Implement nationally appropriate social protection systems and measures for all, including floors, and by 2030 achieve substantial coverage of the poor and the vulnerable.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.2 By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.

Focal users: Narcya Manjate Chilengue; Salesio  Missomal; Mariam Dembele; Alwin Nijholt
2022 Narrative: In 2022, UNICEF facilitated access to improved durable water service to 126,255 people, 75 per cent of them in humanitarian contexts, which represents 153 per cent of the planned target. 90 per cent of this total was achieved in rural areas where the water services coverage is 1.8 times less than urban areas. Two major milestones this year were the ‚Äòfirst stone‚Äô ceremony for the Murrupula town centralized water supply system in Nampula and the handover of 21 solar-powered water system reinforcing UNICEF‚Äôs experience in resilient water infrastructures. More efforts are needed to continue piloting management modalities that ensure sustainability.Ôªøn 2022, 126,255 people had access to improved durable water (Basic + or above service level) with UNICEF support which represents 153 per cent of the expected target. This over-achievement could be attributed to durable water supply solutions implemented in humanitarian contexts: 94,399 additional people counting for 75 per cent of the total not included in the initial planning. As planned, 90 per cent (113,279) of this total was achieved in rural areas where water services coverage is 4.5 times less than in urban contexts. Main water supply interventions involved construction and/or rehabilitation of boreholes equipped with handpumps (273 in total), followed by multi-use solar-powered water supply systems (21), small water supply systems built as extensions of centralized systems (two) in six provinces: Sofala, Manica,Tete, Zambezia, Nampula and Cabo Delgado. In addition, 2,595 new households were connected to six water supply systems built with UNICEF Mozambique support in Inhambane province and for which new connections are attributed to UNICEF‚Äôs support during post-investment 10 years period. Finally, through UNICEF‚Äôs contribution to National Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Programme (PRONASAR) Common Fund, 588 additional people also gained access to improved durable water. In urban contexts, the implementation of the Accelerating Sanitation and Water for All programme made a big step with the initiation of works for the centralized water system in Murrupula town in Nampula province. In support to the innovative/blended financing initiative to increase water access in small towns, UNICEF completed the feasibility studies for 35 small-towns water systems that might be funded using this scheme. Besides, UNICEF Mozambique supported scaling up the revolving fund approach to increase the number of household connections in small towns, in coordination with the USAID-funded initiative WASH Transform and the Dutch-funded initiative PO75. The main challenges faced during the implementation of water supply interventions were linked to the limited capacity government decentralized structures at provincial and district level negatively impacting timely completion of procurement processes and supervision. In the case of Cabo Delgado, in addition to it, the deterioration of the security situation continued to be a challenge, resulting in frequent interruption of construction works. Limited technical and mobilizing capacity of private contractors, such as lack of sufficient trained staff, cash flow and required equipment, also constrained the completion of some planned interventions. UNICEF‚Äôs technical assistance and continuous capacity building activities were crucial to overcome these challenges.  In terms of sustainability, the first nationwide sustainability check for rural WASH infrastructures was finalized and indicated a medium score of 66.1 for the country. Technical factors such as lack of post-construction services provided by Planning and Infrastructures District Services (SDPI), the absence of a mechanism to report breakdowns or supply chain and warehouse for spare parts were pointed out proving the necessity of exploring new management modalities and providing stronger support to community and private operators.
2023 Narrative: Improved, resilient, safe, and sustainably managed water services were particularly relevant in 2023 due to the cholera outbreak and Freddy cyclone (February-March 2023) where water services in urban and rural contexts were damaged putting burden on health for children and their caretakers to recover from cholera and other water linked disease.The regular programme made steady progress to increase access to water services, reaching 40,448 people during the year through the construction of 18 solar water supply systems and 14 boreholes with handpump in rural area. In urban context, the Murrupula small town water supply system was finalized as part of the ASWA II programme for Mozambique, providing access to a basic+ or safely managed water supply services for 13,500 people. This number will progressively increase in the coming years as household connections will be further rolled-out through the revolving fund mechanism. The revolving fund mechanism was also structurally supported by UNICEF, whereby 2,397 additional household connections (10,563 people) were installed in 14 small towns countrywide, where UNICEF share was 17% (408 households, 1,796 people). During 2023, 651 households (2,864 people) obtained access to a safely managed water supply service in the small towns where UNICEF invested in former years.Humanitarian activities added 231,639 people with (restored) access to water through durable solution in emergency; a significant effort, was done for the rehabilitation and disinfection of 586 boreholes and wells with handpump, after flooding and contamination that occurred due to the Freddy cyclone impact. Those interventions were designed with a ‚Äúbuilding back better‚Äù approach, to make them resilient for future climatological events. In the humanitarian context of the Cabo Delgado crisis, small town (urban) systems rehabilitation and extension in Cabo Delgado were completed reaching 62,606 people from IDP and host communities.To respond to the challenges of the hydrogeological complexity, a hydrogeological study including geophysical survey was completed in 15 critical communities in the district of Nacala a Velha. A similar study is also underway in 30 communities in the Memba district with the aim of locating potential sites for boreholes drilling for water supply. Also, to respond to the challenge of quality control in the borehole drilling for water supply, a drilling training was carried out in Cabo Delgado province and was attended by 40 trainees from government and private sector contractors, jointly facilitated by UNICEF and SDC. This training module will also be replicated in other provinces in collaboration with other WASH partners. To reinforce the capacity of the provinces in quality control, in addition to the training mentioned above, UNICEF acquired equipment (borehole camera, depth meter, water quality analysis kits) to be allocated in each of the 4 priority provinces (Cabo Delgado, Nampula, Zambezia and Sofala), where training sessions are also planned for the correct use of the equipment.Between the main challenges are the capacity of government partners to absorb the needs for programme design and tendering, and also the limited capacities of the private sector for the implementation of quality infrastructures.

Outcome: Outcome 1: By 2024, the most vulnerable and excluded groups have improved quality of life with rights-based, gender-sensitive, inclusive, equitable access and utilization of essential social services  in an environment free of discrimination and violence including in humanitarian situations.
Output: OUTPUT 1.2: Capacity of national and sub-national institutions to provide quality, equitable, inclusive and decentralized social services is enhanced.
Sub-Output: Support essential food, nutrition and quality water and sanitation services
Description: UNICEF leverage on the Ministry of Gender and Social Protection safety nets programme to ensure that some of the cash transfers are used to buy more and better-quality food. This helps ensure that families are knowledgeable and can maintain an adequate level of food consumption, which is essential for good health. UNICEF supports the National Food Fortification Alliance to conduct regular assessments of wheat flour, vegetable oil, and cooking salt on the local market are fortified with the needed nutrients as a mitigating approach to addressing the high level of micronutrient deficiencies(malnutrition) amongst the Liberian population, especially pregnant women and children. The county and district WASH Profiles and development plan activities were completed in February 2024 for six selected counties. The County WASH Development Plan aims to support the government's WASH goals by providing a strategic framework for equitable, safe, affordable, and sustainable water supply and sanitation services for all Liberians. The plan's overall objective is to reduce the risk of fecal-oral diseases and exposure to WASH-related diseases.
Agencies: United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations World Food Programme; World Health Organization
Contributing partners: Core Funding; Government of Germany; Government of Norway; WFP 2030 Fund; World Food Programme Multilateral Fund
Implementation partners: Liberian Ministry of Agriculture; Liberian Ministry of Education; Liberian Ministry of Internal Affairs

2022 Narrative: Completed Liberia WASH data collection and submission for global dash board reporting cycle of Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking Water (GLAAS). Supported food security, livelihoods and market survey. 3-Enhanced food safety and food disease surveillance through National capacity building of built Environmental Health Technicians (EHTs) from 3 selected counties (Montserrado, Bong, and Grand Bassa) Built the capacities (skills and competencies) of 40 frontline service providers and 58 community dwellers on essential nutrition actions (ENAs) through the establishment of Baby Friendly Hospital Initiatives (BFHI )facilities and mother-support groups to improve maternal and child nutrition practices.
2023 Narrative: World Health OrganizationSupported the development of the WASH road map and the International Food Safety Authority Network (INFOSAN) road map, commemorated World Food Safety Day, and celebrated World Breastfeeding Week.UNICEF: The WASH Joint Sector Review (JSR), supported by UNICEF, has been successfully completed, and the report is in the process of being printed. Prior to the JSR, the Sector Performance Report was also compiled and is undergoing printing. Conversations centered around the integration of climate-resilient development within WASH sector plans during the JSR, contributing insights to shape the forthcoming Water Supply and Sanitation Policy (WSSP) for 2023‚Äì2027. According to the joint monitoring report by UNICEF and WHO, the percentage of people who had access to at least basic drinking water remained at 76% in 2023. This signifies that the population coverage for basic water supply stands at 65% in rural areas and 85% in urban areas.World Food ProgrammeThrough this intervention, 20 school teachers in Bong and Montserrado enhanced their capacity in provision alternative learning for out of school women. Two hundred (200) rural women received one month training in literacy and numeracy and four months training in vegetable production which developed their skills for alternative livelihoods, increased their reduced their vulnerability to food insecurity.
2024 Narrative: WHO supported of the training of 56‚Ä¨ Environmental and Occupational Health Technicians at national and subnational levels in the use of WHO WASH-FIT Tool in readiness for the assessment and use of the tool to collect WASH-related data from 93 health facilities in the 15 Counties. WHO supported the national food safety authorities to develop case definitions for the 26 foodborne diseases. Terms of Reference for the International Food Safety Authorities Network Focal Point in Liberia, including line ministries, agencies and commissions (MACs), developed with support from WHO to foster coordination and communication on foodborne disease outbreaks and risks to reduce the burden of foodborne illness. WHO supported the National WASH Commission to conduct the 2024-2025 Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation (and Drinking Water GLAAS) for Liberia, and validated and submitted the report.   WHO supported of the training of 56 Environmental and Occupational Health Technicians on the use of WHO WASH-FIT Tool that facilitated the collection of WASH related data from 93 health facilities across the 15 counties. To enhance foodborne disease surveillance, WHO supported the national food safety authorities in developing case definitions for the 26 foodborne diseases. Terms of reference (TOR) for the International Food Safety Authorities Network (INFOSAN) Focal Point in Liberia, including line ministries, agencies and commissions (MACs) developed with support from WHO to foster coordination and communication on foodborne disease outbreaks and risks to reduce the burden of foodborne illness.    Provided technical and financial support to the National WASH Commission to conduct the 2024/2025 Cycle of the Global Analysis and Assessment of Sanitation and Drinking Water (GLAAS) Country Survey, with report validated and submitted. The county and district WASH Profiles and development plan activities were completed in February 2024 for six selected counties. SDG Targets: 1.1 By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.,1.4 By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.,1.5 By 2030, build the resilience of the poor and those in vulnerable situations and reduce their exposure and vulnerability to climate-related extreme events and other economic, social and environmental shocks and disasters.,2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,2.3 By 2030, double the agricultural productivity and incomes of small-scale food producers, in particular women, indigenous peoples, family farmers, pastoralists and fishers, including through secure and equal access to land, other productive resources and inputs, knowledge, financial services, markets and opportunities for value addition and nonfarm employment.,2.4 By 2030, ensure sustainable food production systems and implement resilient agricultural practices that increase productivity and production, that help maintain ecosystems, that strengthen capacity for adaptation to climate change, extreme weather, drought, flooding and other disasters and that progressively improve land and soil quality.,2.a Increase investment, including through enhanced international cooperation, in rural infrastructure, agricultural research and extension services, technology development and plant and livestock gene banks in order to enhance agricultural productive capacity in developing countries, in particular least developed countries,5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,5.4 Recognize and value unpaid care and domestic work through the provision of public services, infrastructure and social protection policies and the promotion of shared responsibility within the household and the family as nationally appropriate.

Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Establish gender responsive water use associations
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2024 Narrative: FAO rehabilitated 59 micro watersheds through establishing water and soil conservation measures such as planting fodder along trenches to feed livestock and reduce run-off, and trees along contour and land boundaries to secure land tenure and soil retention. Rehabilitated 3 valley dams constructed by the government in Katakwi (Cheele), Sembabule (Rwampara) and Nakaseke (Wakyato) that leaked and would not hold water. A cattle market was constructed and handed over to communities in Cheele. The total capacity of these valley tanks is at least 450,000 cubic meters of water.

2022 Narrative: A total of 20 water harvesting infrastructures and nature-based solutions were optimized serving more than 170,500 households (50% women-headed households representing (Somaliland: 91,598HH; Puntland:78,902HH). 6,285 ha of rangelands were rehabilitated. This include:600 ha in Somaliland and 5,685 ha in Puntland. This has substantially enhanced the resilience and improved livelihoods of more than 50,000 households (42% women-headed households) as a result of adopting sustainable practices for natural resources management at the local level. In addition, a total of 640 community resource persons (40% women) were trained in Integrated Water Resources Management for Rangeland Improvement and Livestock Value Chain while 350 people (20% women) benefited from short-term jobs for construction works linked to climate adaptation

2024 Narrative: The Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS) is an international household survey programme developed and supported by UNICEF. MICS is designed to collect estimates of key indicators that are used to assess the situation of children and women. The Nigerian Government has implemented 6 rounds of MICS surveys with support from UNICEF. MICS 7, expected to be released in 2026, will provide reliable data to determine the progress of the Government‚Äôs Renewed Hope Agenda and Health SWAP and establish a baseline for the 2027 ‚Äì 2031 Country Programme cycle. The MICS programme in Nigeria is centered around Government ownership and leadership. It includes dedicated efforts to strengthen the national and subnational capacity of the Government to conduct high-quality MICS surveys. In 2024, the Government of Nigeria, through the leadership of the NBS, kicked off the launch and the survey design of MICS7 in consultation with relevant Ministries at the Federal and State levels.

2024 Narrative: UNICEF has provided extensive support to the Ministry of Water and Environment (MOWE) and local governments to improve sustainable access to safe water, particularly in climate-vulnerable communities. The organization has invested in groundwater assessments, sustainable abstraction, and early warning systems to prevent water scarcity crises. UNICEF has also supported the implementation of solar-powered mini water systems in schools and healthcare facilities, ensuring long-term water security for thousands of people.

2024 Narrative: UNICEF has worked closely with the Ministry of Health (MOH), the Ministry of Water and Environment (MOWE), and local governments to eliminate open defecation and promote basic sanitation in both rural and urban areas. The organization has led sanitation and hygiene interventions in 12 districts, supporting Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) and Market-Based Sanitation approaches. These initiatives have contributed to 71,736 people gaining access to basic sanitation services, bringing targeted communities closer to achieving Open Defecation Free (ODF) status.

2023 Narrative: The ToR for the Water Desalinisation plants, has been drafted after completion of technical and socioeconomic assessment of 5 water sources in Puntland. The ToR has been advertised and shortlisting of the vendors has been flinalised. The shipments, assembly and installment of the Water Desalinisation plant, will start 3rd week Dec or 1st of January. The works is expected for completed by end of February. The project will generate an average of 40,000 liters of clean and potable water per day to serve around 2.000 people per day with 20 liters each, against the minimum standard of 15 liters per day per person. As a result, delivering safe and clean water to selected site in Puntland (Qarho/Waaciye).
2024 Narrative: The project has been completed and commisioned. Also, through investment established a PPP arrangement. The water capacity has been increased from initially planned 40,000 liters a day to 100,000 litres a day to a communityh 8300 in Waaciye towm, Qardho of Puntland. 8300 (838 households) people benefitted from the project with clean and safe water

2023 Narrative: UNESCO fosters sound water management for climate-resilient communities by supporting countries to address complex interrelated water challenges critical in achieving agenda 2030 (especially SDG 6) and other international agendas where water plays an important role including the Paris Agreement and the Sendai framework on disaster risk reduction, approach. According to a report from UNESCO, the City Blueprint is of utmost importance as extreme weather events can leave city streets underwater in no time or protracted drought which renders a city‚Äôs water supply incapable of meeting its needs. Scientific reports have shown that Climate change, urbanization, water pollution, and inadequate maintenance of water and wastewater infrastructures in cities may lead to flooding, water scarcity, adverse health effects, and rehabilitation costs that may overwhelm the resilience of cities. Furthermore, Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) is hindered by water governance gaps and a lack of data. There is, therefore, the need to have a standardized indicator framework for urban Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM), and the City Blueprint Framework (CBF) Approach provides this framework as well as enhances the transition towards water-wise cities, by city-to-city learning.UNESCO has been working with relevant authorities to implement the CBF approach to help countries, including Nigeria, to achieve water security. During the first phase of the work, UNESCO Abuja office joined efforts with the Regional Center for Integrated River Basin Management (RC-IRBM) Kaduna to implement CBF in Abuja and Lagos. There is now a need to cover cities in Nigeria and this will require young water professionals who are knowledgeable in applying the tool. It is in that vein, UNESCO has joined efforts with the Nigeria Integrated Water Resources Management Commission (NIWRMC), to organize the training of City Blueprint Framework (CBF) for Urban Water Management held on Thursday 17th August 2023, at Rockview Royale Hotel, Abuja, Nigeria. The training had the following objectives: Strengthen the Capacity of technical officers of the Nigerian Integrated Water Resources Management Commission (NIWRMC) to implement the City Blueprint Framework (CBF) approach; for urban water management.  Adopt a project concept focused on CBF, for possible fund mobilization.  The 50 Participants at the training included staff of the Nigerian Integrated Water Resources Management Commission (NIWRMC), Federal Capital Development Authority (FCDA), Abuja Environmental Development Board (AEPB), Federal Capital Territory Water Board (FCTWB), National Water Resources Institute (NWRI), the Regional Centre for Integrated River Basin Management Commission (RC-IRBM), Nigerian National Commission for UNESCO (Natcom-UNESCO) and UNESCO Abuja Office.  Result of the training activity included the following Participants received information and were sensitized on the City Blueprint Framework approach. The Capacity of young technical officers of the Nigerian Integrated Water Resources Management Commission (NIWRMC) and some relevant stakeholders in FCT, strengthened on the implementation of City Blueprint Framework (CBF) approach; for urban water management. Training Materials developed for City Blueprint Framework (CBF) approach. A draft project proposal on ‚ÄúCity Blueprint Framework (CBF) Approach for Sustainable Water Management in Nigerian Cities‚Äù was discussed and adopted by experts and stakeholders present. The proposal will be fully developed for fund mobilization
2024 Narrative: Groundwater is widely used in Nigeria because it brings large economic benefits per unit volume, it is locally available, drought resilient and has quality requiring minimal treatment. The reliability of supply of groundwater, uniform quality and temperature, relatively good turbidity and pollution free, minimal evaporation losses, and low cost of development are attributes which make groundwater more attractive when compared to other sources. Therefore, there is the need to assess this important resource with a view of providing the necessary scientific information for policy and discission making, planning and sustainable management.  In 2024 two workshops was implemented within the framework of the UNESCO Intergovernmental Hydrology programme to elaborate the following studies 1)     Groundwater Quality Assessment - building from the City Blueprint Framework; to enhance water security in the country and contribute to the Renewed hope Agenda (RHA). Studies will focus on problem of Pollution from Biological (mostly from septic tank and fecal matter from open defecation) and other pollutants. Studies have commenced with an inception phase.  2)     Groundwater Resources Assessments and Sustainable Management for Climate Resilience and Food Security in Nigeria ‚Äì reviewed for fund mobilization 3)     Restoration of Degraded Wetlands in part of Benue Basin for Enhanced Water Management and Food Production - reviewed for fund mobilizationResult will inform policy and strengthen Groundwater governance also contributing to SDG targets 1.5, 5.1, 6.1, 6.2, 6.2, 6.B. 11.5. 11.6, 13.1, 13.2

2023 Narrative: This regional project aims in improving knowledge‚Äêbased management, governance and resources conservation of the Niger Basin and the Iullemeden‚ÄêTaoudeni/Tanezrouft Aquifer System (ITTAS) to support IWRM for the benefit of communities and the resilience of ecosystems.The regional Transboundary Diagnostic Analysis (TDA) and a Strategic Action Programme (SAP) for ITTAS are under development. Stakeholders/sensitization workshop for the pilot project of ITTAS Program in Sokoto State was organized (17-18th October 2023). Several missions and field works were done at Sokoto basin to set up the demonstration pilot project and to gather data and information for ITTAS database. Water quality assessment in the Iullemeden basin was done through in-situ measurement of physical parameters and laboratory assay of chemical constituents present in groundwater. The viability of shallow groundwater of the quaternary alluvial aquifers for sustainable irrigated agriculture was also determined. An agreement between Sahara and Sahel Observatory (OSS) and The Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) was signed on December 2023 to implement the pilot project demonstration on the identified pilot site.Trainings were provided to strengthen the capacities of national and regional water managers to process TDA/SAP and specialized aspects of aquifer assessment, modelling, planning and management. Several regional validation workshops have been undertaken so far including: Regional training workshop on Groundwater Modelling (Ouagadougou, 8-12 January 2024); Regional training workshop on TDA/SAP process (Bamako, 26-30 December 2023); Scientific Committee Meeting for Groundwater (Bamako, 20-21 December 2023); 1st Meeting of the implementation of the ITTAS Consultation Mechanism (Bamako, 21-22 December 2023); Regional validation workshop to adopt the ITTAS TDA (Nouakchott, 23-26 October 2023); Regional validation workshop of the TDA regional thematic reports (Socio-Economy, Environment, Climate Change, Governance/Legal aspects) to adopt the ITTAS TDA (Ouagadougou, 14-16 February 2023).

2023 Narrative: Improving Groundwater Governance towards achieving Sustainable Water Security for Human Settlements in NigeriaReports have shown that Nigeria is currently witnessing very large and rapidly growing urban Human settlements that are dependent on private water wells and bore holes, despite the fact that the coverage of public water supply has also expanded. Unfortunately, since the groundwater is a hidden source, less attention is given to its adequate governance, investments in infrastructure, trained professionals, and knowledge. There is also the problem of Inadequate data and information for robust policy and proper planning that interlinks groundwater with sustainable development factors like climate change adaptation, education, health, wealth creation and gender-mainstreaming. To this end UNESCO Abuja joined efforts with the National Water Resources Institute (NWRI), Kaduna, Nigeria, to implement the Sub-project ‚ÄúImproving Groundwater Governance towards achieving Sustainable Water Security for Human Settlements in Nigeria‚Äù. The Sub-Project is being implemented within the framework of UNESCO/Korean Fund in Trust (K-FIT) Project tilted ‚ÄúWater Security for Human Settlements in Developing Countries under Climate Change‚Äù, The Sub-project has the overall objective of improving knowledge-based management and governance of groundwater resources to support Nigeria in achieving sustainable water security for human settlements as well as build resilience to the impact of climate change in Nigeria. The Sub-project is structured around one outcome and four outputs as outlined in the below.¬∑        Outcome: Nigeria Groundwater governance improved to achieve water security for Human settlements as well as build their resilience against climate change.√ò Output N¬∞1.1: Report of desktop review of studies on the effects of climate change on the Nigeria‚Äôs Ground water resources (effect of climate change on quality and availability; implications for human settlements; and suggestions of climate friendly infrastructure);√ò Output N¬∞1.2: Guidelines and strategies for improving groundwater governance for water security and building resilience against the impact of climate change.√ò Output N¬∞1.3  Capacity of the 160 Nigerian groundwater experts from the focused towns  strengthened, to use the Guidelines and tools developed  so as to ensure sustainability of the project beyond UNESCO's support√ò Output N¬∞1.4  Publication of Main Result1) As part of the activities geared towards achieving set objectives of the sub-project, as well as outputs, an inception workshop held from 15th to 16th August 2023. The workshop had the following structure.-         Opening session ‚Äì comprised welcome messages, goodwill messages, overview of the workshop and opening statements.-         The Technical session 1 witnessed presentation on the Overview of the Sub- project: ‚ÄúImproving Groundwater Governance towards achieving Sustainable Water Security for Human  Settlements in Nigeria, after which thoughts on Implementation Strategy for the Sub at the National level was presented. The two presentations were also discussed, and observationsmade.-         Technical Session 2 received presentation on Groundwater Governance in Nigeria: Present situation and Gaps; and ‚ÄúImplications of Groundwater for human settlement; with reference toclimate change‚Äù. These two presentations were also discussed, and observations made.-         The Group work discussed guiding lines and suggested modalities for implementing activities of the Sub-project (specially to achieve Outputs 1.1 and 1.2). The following results were achieved during the inception workshop -         National stakeholders introduced to and acquainted with the Sub-Project ‚ÄúImproving Groundwater Governance towards achieving Sustainable Water Security for Human Settlements in  Nigeria‚Äù -         Modalities formulated for the implementation of activities of the Sub-project; to achieve especially Outputs 1.1 and 1.2.-         A time plan adopted for the sub-project implementation.
2024 Narrative: In 2024 the following three studies were commissioned and finalized.  ¬∑        i) Effects of climate change on Nigeria‚Äôs Ground water resources in Human Settlement; as well as development of guidelines and strategies for improving groundwater governance for water security and building resilience against the impact of climate change¬∑        ii) Assessment of National framework on groundwater governance in Nigeria: a baseline documentation/review of existing water-related laws, policies, and regulations on groundwater governance in Nigeria¬∑        iii) Citizen science-policy nexus in Groundwater Governance in the context of climate change and Sustainable Water Security for Human Settlements in NigeriaReports of the studies which are all peer reviewed and finalized, will be used as important Groundwater governance tools to train water experts in 2025

Sustaining peace marker: 2 - Sustaining Peace is a significant objective
2023 Narrative: National Meeting for Promoting the Designation of Jabi Lake as an Ecohydrology Demonstration Site  UNESCO Regional office Abuja, worked with the Regional Center for Integrated River Basin management (RC-IRBM) to organize a National Meeting for promoting the designation of Jabi Lake as Ecohydrology Demonstration Site . Objectives of the National meeting are the following   Brief the national stakeholders on the 2021 and 2022 Regional Ecohydrology Training Workshops and their objectives, recommendations and agreed workplans;Receive more inputs on the Ecohydrology solutions/demonstration that can be implemented with specific reference to Jabi Lake and as highlighted in the zero draft work document (see the attached report); Present in details the UNESCO application processes for designation of an Ecohydrology Demonstration Site; andDiscuss and produce zero draft of Ecohydrology Demonstration Site card for Jabi Lake. The technical content of the meeting were the following ¬∑        Overview of the 2021 and 2022 Ecohydrology Regional Workshops in Abuja with specific focus on their objectives, recommendations and workplans;¬∑        Presentation of UNESCO-approved application processes for Designation of Ecohydrology Demonstration Sites;¬∑        Jabi Lake: Its historical perspectives in Ecohydrology  IWRM Research and procedures for designation as an Ecohydrology Demonstration Site;¬∑        Drawing examples from other established demonstration sites across the world;¬∑        Design, discuss and finalize a zero-draft document for designation of Jabi Lake as an Ecohydrology Demonstration Site; and¬∑        Technical Assessment Visit to the lake.Main outcome of the meeting were the following -         Framework of the Concept of Jabi Lake Ecohydrology Research-         Elaborated workplan for the designation of Jabi Lake as an Ecohydrology demonstration site
2024 Narrative: Scientific research incorporating human interactions with nature in the context of complex water sciences and management problems provide fundamental feedback for water resources management, along with the application of new tools, approaches and technologies. Ecohydrology research and innovation enables Nature Based Solutions (NBS) that contribute to the improved management of water and enabling protection of ecologically sensitive environments, providing critical services, such as wetlands for sewage treatment and flood mitigation, or mangroves to reduce the impact of waves, storm surge and coastal erosion. The principles of ecohydrology provide a framework as to the use of ecosystem processes as basin management tools.UNESCO supports member to use ecohydrology research in water management (especially Integrated Water Resources Management) through establishment of Ecohydrology demonstration sites. Such site enhances the sustainability potential at the catchment level by promoting holistic ecohydrological approaches and sharing best practices. Ecohydrology demo sites contributes to improving water quality, conserving biodiversity and ecosystems, build resilience to climate change and impacts, supports culture and education, and improve law, water governance. In 2024, UNESCO worked with the UNESCO Category 2 center, namely Regional Center for Integrated River Basin Management (RC-IRBM) to determine the potentials of designating River Ethiope in Delta state as an Ecohydrology Demonstration Site

Gender marker narrative: The primary objective of the project was to enhance the livelihoods of community members affected by the aftermath of Cyclone Idai. It aimed to address various activities impacting both men and women within the selected district. The project undertook extensive road rehabilitation efforts in Chipinge and Chimanimani, resulting in improved road networks. This rehabilitation significantly enhanced access to healthcare facilities and, in certain instances, to local markets. Additionally, the project successfully constructed the Jopa Women's Market specifically designed to provide women with an improved and conducive structure for selling their produce.

Output: OUTPUT 1.3: Equitable access to basic social services is strengthened, benefitting vulnerable, marginalized and displacementaffected people.
Sub-Output: Emergency Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support to Crises affected population of Somali region, Ethiopia
Description: Emergency Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support to Crises affected population of Somali region, Ethiopia.The proposed intervention will provide live-saving humanitarian assistance focusing on WASH interventions to targeted internally displaced people (IDPs) in Tuliguled woreda (Somali region), cluster-identified priority locations for intervention. The project will mainly focus on lifesaving water and sanitation support for IDPs and conflict affected areas, as well as hygiene promotion and ongoing capacity building for local communities. To ensure a well-coordinated response, IOM will work in close collaboration with National and sub-national WASH cluster focal points, Camp Coordination and Camp Management (CCCM), Health and protection clusters to ensure overall coordination and inclusive response.
Implementation partners: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia Disaster Risk Management Commission
SDG Targets: 3.7 By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.,3.8 Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.,6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
SDG Goals: 3 Good Health and Well-being; 6 Clean Water and Sanitation

2023 Narrative: In 2023, an estimated 16,784 people (Target 20,000), including about 3,500 children gained enhanced access to safe water services in areas along the northern frontiers of the country under an initiative to enhance resilience in nine communities affected by the Sahel spill-over (beneficiaries included both host communities and people displaced by conflict in Burkina Faso).The National Water Policy has been revised with technical and financial support from UNICEF and is undergoing review for adoption at the cabinet level. Despite delays to enable further cross-sectoral interactions, the approval is expected in early 2024.

A total of 7,600 persons (4,530 females, 2,470 males) have access to improved water supply from Rehabilitation of two solar boreholes in Taraba and Akwa Ibom State; Installation of two Handpump boreholes at Ikyogen settlement; 12 water user committees established for Operation and maintenance of the facilities for sustainability in Akwa Ibom and Taraba State.

Plan name: UNSDCF 2022 - 2026
Outcome: By 2026, all people in Zimbabwe, especially the most vulnerable and marginalized, benefit from greater environmental stability and robust food systems in support of healthy lives and equitable, sustainable and resilient livelihoods.
Output: Output 2.3: Strengthened gender responsive policy, regulatory, public and private finance environment to transform agrifood systems and promote  sustainable natural resource management
Sub-Output: Climate Adaptation Water and Energy Programme in Zimbabwe - UNDP
Description: The CAWEP Project is a 3-year project which aims to support the Government of Zimbabwe attain its climate change goals. The project will support vulnerable communities and institutions‚Äô adaptation and resilience capacity to climate shocks. This project will support the development of climate resilient, multiple water use and renewable energy infrastructure in vulnerable communities of Zimbabwe to enable continued access to water for productive and household use, including during droughts and floods, and improved access to clean and affordable energy to support economic activities with the intention of supporting more sustainable livelihoods‚Äô outcomes. The project will align and contribute towards the Government of Zimbabwe's (GoZ) climate change priorities outlined in various strategies, such as its National Development Strategy, Nationally Determined Contributions, and the National Climate Policy among others. The project has a multifaceted approach to climate adaptation and resilience building.
Contributing partners: United Kingdom Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office
Implementation partners: Zimbabwe  Ministry of Environment, Climate, Tourism and Hospitality
SDG Targets: 13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,13.3 Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.,13.b Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

2023 Narrative: Technical support is being provided to the Ghana Education Service (GES) and the Ghana Health Service (GHS) to strengthen health/education sector ownership for service coverage and their effective management for sustainability. Initial discussions were held with the Ministry of Education and GES at a stakeholder forum on system strengthening for the sustainable management of operation and maintenance for WASH in Schools. After this forum, WASH partners met with the Ghana Education Service to conduct a causality analysis on sustainability challenges.UNICEF, together with the World Bank, WaterAid and WHO have had engagements on supporting a coordination platform for WASH/IPC in the health sector. UNICEF also hosted a similar engagement on aligning development partner support for WASH in Health Care Facilities.For menstrual health and hygiene (MHH), UNICEF led the completion of a study on Access, Affordability and Safety of Menstrual Hygiene Materials. Within the reporting period, UNICEF expanded a prior partnership with the Ghana Standards Authority (GSA) to support development of standards for reusable sanitary pads. As a testament to UNICEF‚Äôs influencing role, GSA nominated UNICEF as part of the three-member country team for International Standards Office Technical Committee on standards for menstrual products.

2022 Narrative: In 2022, the UNICEF's WASH programme provided access to safe drinking water services for over 2.2 million people. A critical component of these schemes was the delivery of up to 175 solar-powered water systems, contributing to climate risk mitigation and reduction of greenhouse gases. To promote sustainability in the sector, the national Village Level Operation and Maintenance strategy was finalized, launched and rolled out in about 300 communities who have now instituted facility management models for their water facilities. UNICEF‚Äôs direct contribution to the National open defecation free (ODF) drive resulted in the achievement of one ODF state (Jigawa) and 85 ODF local government areas (LGAs), with 15 of these attained in 2022. Consequently, over 7.9 million people are living in ODF-certified communities. Furthermore, UNICEF developed and promoted equitable gender-sensitive WASH services in 91 schools, 32 health care centres and in public places.

2024 Narrative: WHO supported the development of training materials and supported the facilitated workshops that empowered adolescents to assume leadership roles as health ambassadors. In collaboration with the Ghana Education Service (GES) and Ghana Health Service (GHS), WHO assessed Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) facilities in participating schools. 2023 Narrative: Weather and Climate data products from WMO global centres under the framework of the WMO Integrated Processing and Prediction System (WIPPS) supported the preparation of localized long-term, and medium to short-term forecast in Nigeria. This included the development of the 2023 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) produced by the Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMet) and presented on 24 January and the 2023 Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) developed and presented by the Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) on 17 February 2023.  The SCP by NiMet and the AFO by NIHSA was a significant source of information for the development of the 2023 climate-related disaster preparedness and mitigation strategies by the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA) in a two-day technical expert meeting on 1 and 2 March 2023. Weather and Climate data products from WMO guaranteed the quality, accuracy and timeliness of weather forecast and prediction services provided by NiMet such as the aeronautical meteorological services to the aviation sector throughout in 2023 and downscaling of weather and climate information to farmers in various states. Beyond the dissemination of the SCP to the public including hundreds of farmers‚Äô associations across the country, NiMet also used the 2023 SCP for targeted awareness activities to directly reach 2,680 farmers (40% Female and 60% male) in various states with support from partners. These include the downscaling of seasonal weather and climate prediction for 2023 and capacity building on the use of seasonal crop weather calendar.
2024 Narrative: Weather and Climate data products from WMO global centres under the framework of the WMO Integrated Processing and Prediction System (WIPPS) were accessed by Nigeria in 2024. These products supported the development of the 2024 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) produced by the Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMet) and presented on 20 February and the 2024 Annual Flood Outlook (AFO) developed and presented by the Nigeria Hydrological Services Agency (NIHSA) on 16 April 2024. This has also supported aeronautical meteorological services to the aviation sector and periodic preparation of localized medium to short-term forecasts in Nigeria between January to December 2024. The SCP by NiMet and the AFO by NIHSA was a significant source of information for the development of the 2024 climate-related disaster preparedness and mitigation strategies by the National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA), and several community sensitization activities by other UN and civil society organizations.

2023 Narrative: Work on the development of a context specific short course on Safely Managed Sanitation (SMS), Climate Resilient Sanitation (CRS) and City-Wide Inclusive Sanitation (CWIS) has begun with consultations held with a sector team drawn from various administrative levels (National, Regional and District) to identify their needs. Subsequently an outline of 12 modules was developed by a team from the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST). An agreement has also been reached to develop and roll out the first edition of the course as a joint venture between UNICEF, WHO and World Bank. Existing resources from these three organizations have been collated to serve as input into the development of the modules. In a meeting with the global team of WHO, a commitment was made to provide technical support in the form of a resource person with knowledge and skills in pedagogy as well as provide financial support. A concept note is currently being prepared as a guide for the various organisations supporting the development of the course.Staff from the Ministry of Sanitation and Water Resources (MSWR) and the National Development Planning Commission (NDPC) also received support for participation in the UN Water Conference as part of capacity building efforts. The Environmental Health and Sanitation Directorate (EHSD) of the MSWR also designated a technical lead person for SMS to strengthen the Ministry's work in the area.

2023 Narrative: The maiden Blood Lead Level (BLL) survey targeting children aged 12-59 months has reached completion across all three ecological zones of Ghana. Among the 3,227 participants, a notable 53.5% (1,785) exhibited BLL above 5ug/dl. UNICEF has played a pivotal role in not only executing the survey but also supporting a high-level dissemination of results to the Ghana Health Service and other key stakeholders, reinforcing a commitment to data-driven action. UNICEF celebrated International Lead Poisoning Prevention Week (ILPPW 2023) through various platforms. A symposium for 265 school children and a health webinar for 49 health workers were organized. Approximately 1,500 individuals were reached through national television and radio discussions. UNICEF is supporting the Ghana Health Service to train national trainers across all 16 regions on air pollution and its impact on vulnerable populations.

2024 Narrative: Dialogues with community leaders, youth and women groups across twelve (12) districts resulted in community-level actions and strategies on tackling environmental risks ‚Äì e.g. pollution, poor WASH, mercury use mining. These fed into a policy dialogue with key stakeholders and informed the development of district specific action plans, to enable district health systems to respond to safeguarding the environment and water bodies in mining and forest communities.

2024 Narrative: FAO: National Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy developed:FAO, in collaboration with the Ministry of Water and Environment, the Ministry of Gender, and other relevant government ministries and civil society organizations (CSOs), successfully supported the development of the National Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy. This strategic document provides a framework to mainstream gender considerations into climate change policies, programs, and interventions, ensuring inclusivity and gender-responsive climate action at all levels.FAO played a key role in supporting the development of the Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy by providing technical expertise, multi-sectoral coordination, and stakeholder engagement. It collaborated with government institutions to bridge climate policies with gender considerations, facilitated consultations with CSOs and communities to ensure inclusivity, and contributed to policy drafting and review. FAO‚Äôs efforts ensured the strategy aligns with national priorities and international frameworks like the Paris Agreement and SDGs, promoting gender-responsive climate action.The Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy marks a significant step toward gender-responsive climate policies. FAO remains committed to supporting capacity-building for policymakers, ensuring effective implementation, and facilitating resource mobilization to advance gender-inclusive climate actions. This initiative strengthens resilience and inclusivity in national climate strategies.

Output: Output 3.2.1: Strengthened capacity of government and non-government institutions at regional, national and sub-national level to uphold positive social, cultural norms, values and practices that promote human rights, equality and non-discrimination.

Agencies: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
Contributing partners: European Union; Swedish International Development Agency
Implementation partners: Uganda Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries (MAAIF); Uganda Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social Development; Uganda Ministry of Water and Environment
SDG Targets: 5.1 End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.,5.2 Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.,5.3 Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.,5.c Adopt and strengthen sound policies and enforceable legislation for the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of all women and girls at all levels.

2024 Narrative: FAO: National Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy developed (Draft):FAO, in collaboration with the Ministry of Water and Environment, the Ministry of Gender, and other relevant government ministries and civil society organizations (CSOs), successfully supported the development of the National Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy. This strategic document provides a framework to mainstream gender considerations into climate change policies, programs, and interventions, ensuring inclusivity and gender-responsive climate action at all levels.FAO played a key role in supporting the development of the Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy by providing technical expertise, multi-sectoral coordination, and stakeholder engagement. It collaborated with government institutions to bridge climate policies with gender considerations, facilitated consultations with CSOs and communities to ensure inclusivity, and contributed to policy drafting and review. FAO‚Äôs efforts ensured the strategy aligns with national priorities and international frameworks like the Paris Agreement and SDGs, promoting gender-responsive climate action.The Climate Change and Gender Action Plan and Strategy marks a significant step toward gender-responsive climate policies. FAO remains committed to supporting capacity-building for policymakers, ensuring effective implementation, and facilitating resource mobilization to advance gender-inclusive climate actions. This initiative strengthens resilience and inclusivity in national climate strategies.

2023 Narrative: The Monitoring Construction / rehabilitation of basic infrastructure related to land and water will be carried out only after the Spacial Development Framework has been implemented and has shown some guidelines on what to do and where. This contruction and rehabilitation is planned to start in 2024.UN-Habitat conducted training sessions to raise awareness and define focal points for the adaptation of the Spatial Development Framework (SDF) and Transhumance Tracking Tool (TTT) methodologies with representatives of livestock breeders (35 participants, including 6 women) from different sectors of the Bafata and Gab√∫ Regions.UN-Habitat also conducted training on the methodology of the SDF (28 participants, including 3 women) in Bafata and Gabu. The SDF methodology is currently in the implementation process. This training aims to raise awareness, empower local focal points, and enable the spatialization of different infrastructures and characteristics identified in the collectively prepared questionnaire at the workshop. Consequently, it is expected to facilitate understanding of the region's diverse needs, guiding decision-making regarding future interventions, particularly in pastoralism infrastructures.Subsequently, UN-Habitat held a validation meeting for the territorial unit in Gab√∫ and Bafat√° to approve the proposed territorial unit, applying the SDF methodology. In December/23 and January/24, function identification inventories were conducted in 74 communities in the Gabu and Bafat√° regions. The collected data are currently in the consolidation and analysis phase.The results of the spatial structure will be validated between February and March of 2024 with relevant project stakeholders, including separate spaces for women and youth to express their needs within the defined spatial structure. Once validated, the team can collaboratively prioritize zones and types of interventions based on ground evidence to support transhumance dynamics.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported the development and validation of a comprehensive study on WASH system resilience in 2023. The MSWR lead will be supported to develop a management response plan to address the key recommendations of the study. The response plan is also expected to lead the process of developing a WASH System Resilience Strategy and Guidelines for Ghana. UNICEF continues to support modelling of interventions and documentation for scale-up. In 2023, the Urban Sanitation Project close-out event and evaluation were undertaken. The evaluation highlighted significant lessons in cost-effective programming and scalable approaches for Ghana. UNICEF also commissioned and finalized a study on Access, Affordability and Safety of Menstrual Hygiene Materials and the outcomes will be used for advocacy for improving menstrual health and hygiene for girls in Ghana.
