2023 Narrative: The Integrated Water Resource Management project was successful in developing a gender-sensitive National IWRM Strategy, accompanied by an implementation roadmap and strategic results framework through a multi-stakeholder consultative process. Three (3) coordination meetings around IWRM and Water Governance. These include:-   The launching of the Water Sector Coordination Facility in September 2022 by the MOEWR.-   The high-level Water Sector Development Forum in March 2023.-   The Integrated Water Sector Development Task Force Meeting in May 2023.A total of 210 people (30% women) have been sensitized through these meetings on IWRM and Water Governance. The coordination meetings have also enabled to gain traction by the political leadership for a comprehensive approach for water governance and IWRM in the changing climatic conditions.The coordination meetings have also enabled to gain traction by the political leadership for a comprehensive approach for water governance and IWRM in the changing climatic conditions.The project was successful in developing a gender-sensitive National IWRM Strategy, accompanied by an implementation roadmap and strategic results framework through a multi-stakeholder consultative process.The National Water Coordination Facility has been established in line with the recommendation of National Water Resources Strategy (NWRS, 2021-25). The facility has five sub-working groups co-chaired by the government and relevant UN agencies including UNDP, FAO, UNEP, UNICEF.. Furthermore, concept note for allocation of resources from Somalia Joint Fund (SJF) to support Water Governance has been drafted by UNDP and MOEWR.National Water Management Task Force has been established to coordinate Flood, emergency relief, and Integrated Water Resource Management interventions. This initiative will strengthen the overall frameworks for flood, emergency and Integrated water Resource Management interventions through appropriate coordination and facilitation platforms complimented by a clear financing framework.In response to the need for improved water management in the riverine areas, a comprehensive study for Basin Diagnostic and Strategic Action Plan has been finalised for the Shabelle River through a consultative process engaging a diverse set of stakeholders from key line ministries at the Federal and Member States, researchers, academia and development partners. In addition, MOEWR with support of GEF-LDCF project, has finalised the 5-year Strategic Action Plan, to address the issues and challenges pertaining to water governance, flooding, irrigation and in-country  transboundary river basin management in a changing climatic conditions.A similar comprehensive study for the Basin Diagnostic and Strategic Action Plan for the Juba Basin along with the preparation of prioritized project is also on-going, in partnership with the World Bank funded Somalia Crisis Recovery Project (SCRP). One of the recommendations of the Strategic Action Plan (SAP) for Shabelle River is the establishment of the Shabelle River Basin Management Authority for the operations of the barrages and water allocations for various water user groups. A hydro-climatic modelling study was completed to inform the Strategic Action Plan for Juba River Basin (note: the study is available with the MOEWR).With the aim of assessing the groundwater potential in the river basins, LDCF-GEF project has supported the MOEWR to partner with Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) to undertake the Merti Aquifer Feasibility Study. The aquifer is shared between Somalia and Kenya, and the study will enable the two countries to assess the potential of conjunctive use of groundwater resources with the surface water. In addition, the project was also seen to undertake capacity-building training on IWRM for multi-sectoral stakeholders at the Federal level and the Federal Member States. Also,, the project was also successful in developing and implementing an IWRM Master‚Äôs Degree Programme at the Somalia National University. Thirty (35 ) students (30% female). This initiative will support sustainable water resource management, long-term adaptation to climate change and capacity building of young professionals to implement water  climate initiatives in future.The IWRM LDCF-GEF project supported the establishment of the curricula for TVET with water management focus. Needs assessment for the existing vocational training centers/Institutions have been completed by the MOEWR in consultations with the relevant institutions and actors at the Federal and Federal Members States. An agreement has been signed with IHE Delft Institute for Water Education by MoEWR-FGS to implement the recommendations of the needs assessments in the Agriculture, Water, Livestock and Disaster Risk Management sectors and meet the project end target. UNESCO¬¥s International Hydrological Programme (IHP) is the only intergovernmental freshwater initiative institutionalized in the UN system supporting Water Governance.Water quality laboratories assessment has been completed by the Federal Ministry of Energy and Water Resources for Puntland, Galmudug, Southwest, Hirshabelle and Jubaland States. Water Lab equipment has been delivered to Puntland Water Development Agency. Establishment of Water Quality Laboratories and training of water technicians in Hirshabelle, Jubaland, Galmudug and Southwest is on-going.An Online Dashboard has been opertionalised by the MOEWR to coordinate National  sub-national Integrated water interventions across Somalia.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework
Outcome: Outcome 4.2 By 2025, the number of people impacted by climate change, natural disasters, and environmental degradation is reduced
Output: 4.2.2: Enhance resilience of vulnerable communities and ecosystems through implementation of climate change adaptation and mitigation actions
Sub-Output: 2023/2024- 2.2.1:- Transfer of technologies for enhanced climate risk monitoring and reporting on water resources in drought and flood prone areas.
Description: Transfer of technologies for enhanced climate risk monitoring and reporting on water resources in drought and flood prone areas.
Implementation partners: United Nations Development Programme
SDG Targets: 6.b Support and strengthen the participation of local communities in improving water and sanitation management.,6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.5 By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.,6.6 By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.,13.1 Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.
SDG Goals: 6 Clean Water and Sanitation; 13 Climate Action
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
Sustaining peace marker: 0 - Not expected to contribute towards sustaining peace
2023 Narrative: Climate and weather monitoring equipment have been procured and currently installed in collaboration with the Federal Ministry of Energy and Water Resources (MOEWR). The equipment includes 13 synoptic stations and 4 radar river level sensors including fencing, spare parts, secure data server and OM for 4 years. All the Federal Member States are targeted and will benefit from the enhanced capacities of disseminating early warnings on climatic events (droughts and floods). A total of 10 technical staff the MOEWR have been trained on data collection, data treatment (including data quality checks), data analysis, operation, and maintenance (OM) for weather equipment. The installation of 5 synoptic stations and one radar river level sensor have been completed and operational. The installation of the remaining stations is ongoing.The system for better forecasting and occurrence information has been established and is expected to serve more than 500,000 agro-pastoralists with enhanced capacities of disseminating early warnings on climatic events (droughts and floods).Additionally, the project made progress towards the establishment of an NHMS by developing an NHMS Policy that was endorsed by muti-sectoral stakeholders at the Federal and Member States level. The policy endorsed by the Federal Government of Somalia and is the first step towards the establishment of National Hydro-meteorological Services (NHMS). The project has also supported the long-term capacity development plan for operationalization of the NHMS.The Groundwater Development Action plan has been completed in partnership with the MOEWR. A study on groundwater potential sites in the country is also completed jointly by MOEWR, UNDP and FAO. The use of groundwater will increase water access for pastoral communities in drought-affected areas taking into consideration aquifer characteristics, extent, location, recharge, groundwater availability and sustainable yields.
2024 Narrative: A major milestone in Somalia's climate resilience is the fully operational National Hydro-Meteorological Service (NHMS), providing essential weather and climate forecasts. With 30% of its workforce being women, NHMS promotes gender equality. The early warning system now reaches over 525,000 agro-pastoralists, helping communities anticipate and respond to climate shocks like droughts and floods.

2023 Narrative: The delivery of various civil works and infrastructures benefited the local communities by contributing to the availability of rainwater for household and livestock use and mitigating flooding and degradation of community land which were well received by local communities.Across Somalia, 19 water harvesting infrastructures and nature-based solutions were optimized serving more than 29,000 households (50% women-headed households representing (Somaliland: 5,000 HH; Puntland: 15,000 HH; Jubaland:3,000 HH and HirShabelle: 6,000 HH).- These include: 3 seed storage centres, and 6 new tree nurseries in Somaliland, 1 earth dam along with auxiliary works, 3 berkads (underground water reserviours), and 2 rangelands rehabilitation in Puntland, 1 flood retention wall and 1 Large scale Fodder production/irrigation scheme +warehouse in Beletweyne district of HirShabelle State and 1 canal rehabilitation and 1 Large scale Fodder production/irrigation scheme +warehouse in Luuq district of Jubaland State. More than 450 people (30% women) benefited from short-term employment ( women vendors and casual labourer)  through the implementation of the nature-based solution (water and climate change adaptation civil works).The IWRM-LDCF2 project has trained over 270 policymakers and planners (30% women) on IWRM principles, and Geospatial knowledge achieving 180% of its End-term target. These trainings have been conducted at the Federal and Federal Member states including , Galmudug, South West, and Jubaland.The Geospatial training organised in Mogadishu benefited more than 30 people (30% women).

2023 Narrative: 3 water catchments have been constructed in Duqaaqo, Afbarwaaqo, and Buqaaloq; these locations were targeted as they were best fit in terms of landscape and conveyance of water flow. The water catchments have provided a meaningful water supply, especially during the rainy season, as they are also fitted with supporting infrastructures such as storage water tanks and distribution pipelines to allow for safe access to water for the communities. So far, 1650 beneficiaries can access water from the water catchments.

2023 Narrative: UNESCO in joint collaboration with ‚ÄúSave the Children/Egypt (STCE)‚Äù as one of the USAID targeting programs, launched a Water/Climate Community - based Education and Awareness/outreach program in Menya governorate, Egypt. Interactive informal water/Climate educational activities aiming to enhance the water conservation culture within school students and local communities were developed, trained and disseminated. Over 2,000 Egyptian community schools facilitators, school teachers, School Students, rural community members, learners of adult education community schools in addition to municipalities officers benefited and involved in this collaboration. The beneficiaries represented rural and urban areas. The activities are mainly focusing on promoting the value of water and the possible climate change impacts in Egypt with special focus on Menya Governorate; encouraging responsible climate change adaptation behaviors and actions toward sustainable water conservation; and emphasizing individual and local communities' responsibility for facing climate change impacts for responsible water behaviour.

Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2023 Narrative: UNESCO is taking a leading role in coordinating the Green Water Accounting thematic component of the international Initiative of ‚ÄúAction for Water Adaptation and Resilience (AWARe) as launched by the Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation of Egypt during COP27. In this regard, UNESCO Cairo supported and co-organized several session within the Sixth Cairo International Water Week, namely: -         Plenary on Green Water for Freshwater Ecosystem Restoration and Adaptation to Climate Change: This plenary highlighted how green water can be accounted for to develop national use plans, adaptation and mitigation strategies, and to protect and restore freshwater ecosystems.  -         Technical session on counting green water in water adaptation measures towards COP 28: This session identified key necessary actions to build the capacities and skills required at the national, regional and global levels to take green water into account in national climate change adaptation plans. More than 100 Egyptian experts, academicians, policy makers and professionals attended and benefited from this activity. Additionally, UNESCO supported the promotion of Egypt established Pan-African Center for Water and Climate Adaptation (PACWA) consolidating Egypt leading role in Africa on water and climate.   Moreover, UNESCO trained 12 Egyptian experts on the incorporating water issues in the National Determined Contribution (NDC) documents in context of Paris Agreement.

2023 Narrative: In 2023, access to basic water supply services was created for an estimated total of 40,317 people including children (20,955 females and 19,362 males) through the construction of 11 climate-resilient water systems (2 Gravity Fed Systems and 9 Solar Powered Motorized Systems). For each of the eleven water supply systems, UNICEF, in collaboration with the relevant ministries (Ministry of Water Resources and Sanitation, and the Ministry of Health), Partner Organisations (CSO and INGO), and the right holders, developed a water safety plan, ensure water is safe from source to point of consumption. UNICEF also facilitated the capacity building of WASHCOMS in over 500 communities through training and the provision of toolkits for the sustainability of completed facilities.  In addition, UNICEF significantly contributed to elevating the learning and quality of care services within schools and health facilities through the provision of water supply services in 13 schools and 11 healthcare facilities. Through the intervention in schools, 8,851 children (4,514 boys; 4,337 girls) have gained access to and utilize basic basic water supply services.   UNICEF further strengthened the capacity of national and district engineers, partner staff, and WASH Committees on the operation and maintenance of WASH facilities including solar-powered motorized boreholes to ensure the sustainability of the water supply facilities.   UNICEF Sierra Leone under the Global Water Leadership Programme (GWLP) funded by FCDO is implementing the WASH Climate Shift activities followed by WASH Joint Sector Review (JSR) preparation. Climate rational, climate risk informed WASH Bottleneck Analysis are in progress. The two days‚Äô WASH Joint Sector Review (JSR) is planned for early 2024 and the preparation is ongoing. Theis will be a milestone to monitor the sector and mobilizing and leverage more resources in WASH sector
2024 Narrative: UNOPS: In 2024, UNOPS conducted technical studies including mapping of customer databases, validation and update of the existing water distribution network, procurement of pipes and fittings for leakage management, and establishment of well-defined District Metering Areas (DMAs) to enable Guma Valley Water Company (GVWC) to carry out proper water balance. Around 90,000 people in Freetown are benefitted from the project interventions.UNCDF: In 2024, 25 water kiosks were constructed and 8 have been officially handed to the City Council, ensuring that some of the most vulnerable communities in Freetown have access to water. These kiosks operate with a sustainable business model, generating revenue through affordable water sales while ensuring consistent maintenance and service delivery. Key to the project‚Äôs success is the appointment of 16 women as kiosk operators (2 per Water kiosks), a first in the city‚Äôs history. This shift has not only improved water access but also empowered women economically and socially, transforming them into decision-makers in the water value chain.‚Ä¢	Each water kiosk is expected to serve approximately 1,000 residents, enabling up to 25,000 residents in Freetown communities to access clean, affordable water, thereby improving public health and well-being.‚Ä¢	Training was successfully completed for 200 women on water kiosk operations and business management, equipping them with skills to manage the kiosks effectively. This milestone was celebrated at a graduation ceremony attended by the Mayor of Freetown, demonstrating high-level endorsement and community recognition.

2023 Narrative: In the reporting year, access to and use of basic sanitation services reached an additional 102,607 people including children (53,355 males and 49252 females), with a total of 171,474 people (89,169 males and 82,305 females) that are now living in open defecation-free in three chiefdoms across Koinadugu, Portloko and Moyamba districts, through the chiefdom-wide approach to ending open defecation. Additionally, 118,692 people have access to, and are using basic hygiene services.  Within the reporting year, UNICEF supported the training and capacity strengthening of various community structures such as Community Hygiene Volunteers, and Village Savings and Loans Associations (VSLAs) for the promotion, monitoring, and sustainability of sanitation in 621 communities in three chiefdoms across Port Loko, Koinadugu and Moyamba Districts.  Regarding WASH in schools and menstrual hygiene management, UNICEF supported 8,851 school children (4,514 boys; 4,337 girls) in 13 schools through the provision of WASH facilities, that incorporated safe spaces for Menstrual Hygiene Management and awareness thereby providing a conducive and hygienic learning environment for girls, further supporting an estimated 1,642 adolescent girls.

2024 Narrative: UNICEFKey Achievements: UNICEF improved community access to clean water and sanitation by strengthening WASH infrastructure and promoting safe hygiene practices. Climate-resilient solar-powered systems provided safe water to 197,000 people, with 39,811 learners benefiting from enhanced school WASH facilities. Community-led sanitation efforts declared 217 villages open defecation-free, benefiting over 54,250 individuals. Emergency responses reached 1.41 million people with safe water and hygiene messaging, addressing cholera and flood-affected areas. UNICEF trained 700 water point committees to sustain infrastructure and engaged 74,716 people in community-led sanitation activities. Schools and healthcare facilities also received support, with solar-powered systems installed in 69 rural health facilities. Advocacy for climate-resilient WASH programming influenced policies, including the Sanitation Bill and Water Works Act.These integrated interventions promoted hygiene practices at household and community levels, enhancing resilience and addressing vulnerabilities in remote and underserved areas‚Äã.Challenges: Climate-related vulnerabilities continue to affect already provided water supply systems; inadequate sanitation infrastructure in underserved regions. Opportunities: Expand solar-powered WASH systems and integrate hygiene education in schools.

2023 Narrative: Continued support provided to the country jointly with local and regional development partners in strengthening of actions for nature actions. These, among others, include interventions met through the Convention for the Protection of the Mediterranean Sea Against Pollution (Barcelona Convention) in line with Egypt‚Äôs national development priorities. The country is, for instance, among the Member States supported to attend the Barcelona Convention's COP 23 in December 2023 at Slovenia's coastal town Portoroz - in addition to ratifying the Convention's Programme of Work (PoW) and budget for the 2024-2025 biennium. Egypt is an active contracting Member State to the Convention and continues to implement its applicable national level policies and other interventions since it entered into force in September 1978.The country's national institutions were also included in Africa-wide efforts to strengthen the capacity for environmental reporting, including in the context of the environmental dimensions of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the Sustainable Development Goals. Egypt was also represented in the UNEP-supported Nineteenth ordinary session of the African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN) that deliberated on regional matters that permeate and shape national policies and institutions on biodiversity and ecosystem management- including contextualized regional approach to the Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework.

Description: This project seeks to increase the resilience of agropastoral communities living in the middle and lowveld regions of Eswatini, who are vulnerable to increases in temperature, drought and heavy rainfall related impacts, by promoting the sustainable management of ecosystems and watersheds. This will be achieved through ecosystem-based adaptation approaches, including sustainable approaches to conserving vegetation, maintaining soil fertility, reducing erosion, increasing the storage and supply of water for agriculture, developing/promoting sustainable agricultural value chains, unlocking public and private-sector finance, and establishing innovative funding mechanisms for sustainable agriculture and restoration. Together these approaches will improve agropastoral livelihoods/incomes, protect and restore biodiversity.

Gender marker narrative: The primary objective of the project was to enhance the livelihoods of community members affected by the aftermath of Cyclone Idai. It aimed to address various activities impacting both men and women within the selected district. The project undertook extensive road rehabilitation efforts in Chipinge and Chimanimani, resulting in improved road networks. This rehabilitation significantly enhanced access to healthcare facilities and, in certain instances, to local markets. Additionally, the project successfully constructed the Jopa Women's Market specifically designed to provide women with an improved and conducive structure for selling their produce.

Sustaining peace marker narrative: Peace may not be the sole focus but it remains a vital component in ensuring that all communities, especially women and youth can fully reap the benefits of rehabilitation efforts.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Partnership Framework (2018-2022)
Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 3 - Sustainable Inclusive Economic Growth & Development
Outcome: Outcome 3.3 - Environmental Sustainability & Food Security
Output: Output 3.3.1 - Human and institutional capacities strengthened to ensure sustainable environmental management and food security.
Sub-Output: 3.3.1.11 - Pillar 2 (SC)- Water Security through scientific cooperation
Description:
UNESCO facilitated the participation of Nigeria in the e-Learning training on ‚Äú Flood Early Waring, Flood Hazard Mapping and Contingency Planning‚Äù. This training will enable Nigeria, set up and operate flood early warning systems. Participation included Nigerian Emergency management Agency (NEMA), National Water Resources Institute (NWRI), Nigerian Hydrological service Agency (NIHSA) and Regional Center for Integrated River Basin management (RC-IRBM)  _x000D_
In 2020 a high level online Advocacy event tagged ‚ÄúWater and Climate Change: Women‚Äôs Coping Strategies In West Africa, was organized via zoom platform. This Online event was jointly organized by UNESCO Multisectoral Regional Office Abuja, UNESCO World Water Assessment Programme (WWAP) Perugia-Italy and UNESCO Category II Center namely; Regional Center for Integrated River Basin Management IRC-IRBM), Kaduna-Nigeria.   Participants/target beneficiaries included water and gender 35 experts from Nigeria ( Men 20: Women 15), The  event featured presentation of the 2019 WWAP Toolkit on sex-disaggregated water data.  ‚ÄúThe toolkit contains a priority topic on water, migration, displacement and climate change, dedicated indicators and the related questions for the collection of data in the field, making it a valuable tool for the collection of much-needed and currently scarce sex-disaggregated water data. The tool kit will be used for the two technical trainings in 2021.
Agencies: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Contributing partners: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation
Implementation partners: FMWRs; RCIRBM
SDG Targets: 2.1 By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.,5.5 Ensure women's full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life,6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.,6.3 By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.,6.6 By 2020, protect and restore water-related ecosystems, including mountains, forests, wetlands, rivers, aquifers and lakes.,8.3 Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.,9.5 Enhance scientific research, upgrade the technological capabilities of industrial sectors in all countries, in particular developing countries, including, by 2030, encouraging innovation and substantially increasing the number of research and development workers per 1 million people and public and private research and development spending.,13.2 Integrate climate change measures into national policies, strategies and planning.,17.1 Strengthen domestic resource mobilization, including through international support to developing countries, to improve domestic capacity for tax and other revenue collection.
SDG Goals: 2 Zero Hunger; 5 Gender Equality; 6 Clean Water and Sanitation; 8 Decent Jobs and Economic Growth; 9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure; 13 Climate Action; 17 Partnerships for the Goals
QCPR function: Capacity Development/Technical Assistance; Data Collection and Analysis; Policy Advice and Thought Leadership
Gender marker: 3 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is the principal objective
Human rights marker: 1 - Limited contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative:
Under the 3.3.11, UNESCO implemented the following activities 
 i) UNESCO supported a young Nigerian water export to  assess the sustainability of Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) in Lagos city, using the City Blueprint Approach  

ii) UNESCO trained 1Nigerian Water experts on Eco hydrological Approach As A Tool For Enhancing Water Quality In West Africa. Introducing participants to basic concepts of Ecohydrology principles, approaches and applications; increasing  knowledge on  Ecohydrology implementation  as an innovative  tool for enhancing Water quality and rendering Ecosystem services; and Providing  a platform for sharing knowledge and information on Ecohydrology activities in the region; thus contributing to national capacities in achieving SDG 6 

iii) UNESCO supported 20 Nigerian water experts to strengthen their capacity on ‚ÄúWater, Gender and Climate Change: better data for better adaptation strategies;. The training culminated in development of case studies   

iv) A Situational Analysis was undertaken for the Nigerian Intergovernmental Hydrology Programme (IHP) and National water Landscape. The analysis was done with a view to strengthen  the capacity of the Nigerian IHP  committee   for better implementation of IHP-IX strategic action plan in 2022 -2029 

v) UNESCO supported capacity strengthening for Monitoring and Evaluation of the Nigerian water sector. 30 Nigerian Water experts trained
2022 Narrative: i)    UNESCO promoted Water Security through scientific cooperation in Ecohydrology. Nigeria was primed to commence implementation of ecohydrology activity at Jabi Lake; especially in the designation of the Lake as Ecohydrology demonstration Siteii) UNESCO trained Nigerian water professionals to promote the designation of ecohydrology demonstration sites and the implementation of integrated and holistic approaches to ecohydrology, within biosphere reserves for improved water management.

This transferred the power of ownership, to the communities, with a business model for operation and maintenance. As a result, there has been over 10% improvement in the functionality rate of water facilities in the areas of intervention.
2024 Narrative: To ensure sustainability challenges of the water supply facilities, 214 additional local area mechanics were trained and continue to provide service for the operation and maintenance of these facilities, even in hard-to-reach areas. Further, UNICEF facilitated the engagement of 67 private sector operators, leading to signed Memorandum of Understanding with communities in the form of public-private-community partnerships for the operation, management and maintenance of their water supply facilities. This facility management model will ensure access to water supply when needed (and reduce downtime when the facilities break down) for about 200,000 people. And strengthened  about 12,004 community-based WASH Committees

2021 Narrative:
One-UN Project on a Water Resources Assessment in the Arid and Semi-Arid Lands of Kenya is a project that was being led by UNEP-Africa Office and UNICEF Regional Office. The first phase of the rapid integrated assessment focused on understanding the available water resources of eight ASAL counties and on proposing measures to improve water security. The eight counties are Garissa, Isiolo, Mandera, Marsabit, Samburu, Tana River, Turkana and Wajir, as these counties have been severely affected by droughts and have been identified as priority counties by the Ministry of Devolution and ASAL. 

In Nov. 2021, UNEP Africa Office conducted a Technical Scoping workshop to review and validate the scope, preliminary content, and structure of the Kenya Forest Assessment Report being jointly prepared by UNEP and the Government of Kenya. This included a technical analysis and endorsement of the applicable geo-spatial data and information (satellite imagery characteristics) that have been identified for use in producing the report.

2024 Narrative: UNICEF:Key Achievements: UNICEF strengthened participatory community interventions and dialogues to enhance preparedness, resilience, and recovery in the face of climate shocks and disasters. Climate-resilient WASH systems provided safe water to 197,000 people, while community-led sanitation efforts declared 217 villages open defecation-free, benefiting over 54,250 individuals. Participatory approaches engaged 700 water point committees to sustain WASH infrastructure, supported by community dialogues promoting hygiene and sanitation practices.In response to disasters like Cyclone Freddy, UNICEF partnered with local institutions to deliver mental health and psychosocial support, community policing, and case management services, reaching 600,000 children and caregivers. Nutrition interventions included mobilizing 1,675 care groups to educate caregivers on optimal child feeding practices, contributing to the treatment of 40,811 children with severe wasting.UNICEF integrated climate-smart agricultural practices into livelihood programs, training over 25,840 individuals in financial literacy, business management, and sustainable farming. Collaborations with schools and community networks promoted resilience through health, SRHR, and nutrition education.Through participatory dialogue and multi-sectoral approaches, these interventions built community capacity to adapt to climate challenges, ensuring sustained access to critical services, improved health outcomes, and stronger resilience against future shocks.Challenges: UNICEF faces challenges in sustaining WASH systems, maintaining community engagement, and responding effectively to disasters. Cultural stigmas around mental health and economic viability issues also pose obstacles. Opportunities/ Priorities: However, opportunities exist in empowering communities through local initiatives, scaling successful interventions, and fostering partnerships for innovative solutions. Continuous dialogues can enhance awareness of health and nutrition, while climate-smart practices improve agricultural sustainability. Engaging youth can cultivate future leaders capable of addressing climate challenges. UNHCR: UNHCR contributed to building resilience of refugees and the host community in Malawi by expanding coverage of parametric insurance in Malawi through ARC replica programme. Through this UNHCR paid a premium of USD 250,000 which resulted into the payout of USD 400,000 which was used to compensate 4000 HHs that were affected by El Nino in Dzaleka camp and the host community.
2025 Narrative: WHO: Provided technical support for risk communication and community engagement.

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Building Peace and Strengthening Governance
Outcome: Outcome 3. Most vulnerable populations including women and children increasingly use improved basic healthcare, nutrition, education and WASH services in South Sudan.
Output: Output 3.1.4 WASH: Vulnerable and emergency-affected people in South Sudan including children and women have access to basic drinking water, sanitation facilities and increased the capacity for effective emergency preparedness, response and recovery for WASH services.
Sub-Output: 3.4.1 - Construction and rehabilitation of water infrastructure like borehole, mini water yards, spring protection, solar water system including urban water system in communities, health facilities and schools
Description: Construction and rehabilitation of water infrastructure like borehole, mini water yards, spring protection, solar water system including urban water system in communities, health facilities and schools
Agencies: International Organization for Migration; United Nations Children's Fund
Contributing partners: International Organization for Migration; United Nations Children's Fund
Implementation partners: CSOs,; Private Contractors
SDG Targets: 6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF: The delivery modalities for providing safe water included water trucking, repair and rehabilitation of 426 hand pumps, drilling 95 new boreholes with handpumps, construction of nine solarized water systems, and establishing and operating 12 SWAT systems. As part of ensuring continuity of water supply during the COVID-19 pandemic, water treatment chemicals were provided to ensure safe water to an estimated 600,000 people connected to the South Sudan Urban Water Corporation = water network in Juba, Wau, and Bor.  UNICEF continued supplying water to the urban areas of Malakal and parts of Jonglei and Upper Nile State through emergency SWATs.
The programme responded to the food and malnutrition crisis and targeted the ten priority counties for provision of WASH in nutrition centres and communities with high GAM levels. In addition to the development program support to health facilities this strategy resulted in more than 171% over-achievement of the targeted support to health facilities (90 supported with WASH facilities against the target of 67).  Additionally UNICEF provided WASH facilities in 87 schools.

IOM: IOM constructed a number of new water sources as part of its response to the WASH needs of urban/rural host communities, as well as those internally displaced by conflict, flooding and/or high levels of food insecurity (31 mechanically drilled boreholes, 26 manually drilled boreholes, 118 borehole rehabilitations, 9 Solarized Water Yards, and 2 SWAT systems). IOM also continued to ensure daily water service provision of IDPs living in Bentiu, Wau and Malakal IDP/PoC camps, by managing, operating and maintaining 2 large-scale water distribution systems (one covering Wau IDP camp and another covering S2 &S3 of Bentiu IDP camp), as well as a large-scale SWAT system in Malakal PoC - all of which hybrid systems (operating both with solar, as well as diesel). As part of its support to other WASH partners operating in Bentiu IDP Camp, IOM also re-activated its Contingency Borehole system whenever needed, providing additional support to Mercy Corps (operating in Sector 1) during 2021. During the last quarter of the year, IOM's water supply system in Wau IDP Camp was entirely solar powered  - reflecting IOM's commitment to transition to a more green approach to WASH service delivery in an emergency context. Access to safe drinking water was also further enhanced through  IOM's WASH Emergency, Preparedness & Response distribution program, whereby WASH NFI Kits containing water treatment products were distributed to a number of IDPs experiencing a range of crisis (31,023 WASH NFI kits, 938 SAM/MAM WASH NFI Kits, 1,500 COVID-19 WASH NFI Kits and 412 HEV-E dedicated WASH NFI Kits). IOM also supported the national C-19 Preparedness & Response Plan by installing and operating 666 handwashing devices in key hotspot areas, whilst supporting 8 Health Facilities and 3 PoEs with IPC/WASH. IOM also contributed to improving water supply at institutional level, by rehabilitating 4 boreholes, drilling 1 and building 1 water yard across 6 different schools.
2022 Narrative: In order to effectively serve the needs of the sector, various approaches and interventions were used to deliver WASH services. Provision of safe water was made possible through construction of new water facilities using mechanized drilling, construction of piped water schemes and rehabilitation of non-functional boreholes, as well as the establishment of surface water treatment (SWAT) systems where possible, such as in internally displaced persons (IDP) camps. UNICEF helped drilling over 100 new boreholes, rehabilitated 141 non functioning boreholes, which includes 37 solar powered water systems, constructed four water treatment plants. In certain areas, such as Juba IDP camp, safe water was primarily delivered through efficient surface water treatment plant. UNOPS drilled 203 boreholes across 10 counties (Juba, Kapoeta North, Rumbek Center, Wulu, Aweil East, Aweil North, Tonj North, Jur River, Ezo, and Ibba)

Strategic priority: Strategic Priority 1 - Building Peace and Strengthening Governance

Description: Support capacity building of community based operation and maintenance system like training to water management or hand pump mechanics;
Agencies: International Organization for Migration; United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; World Health Organization
Implementation partners: CSOs,
SDG Targets: 6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.
2021 Narrative:
UNICEF: Development of a strong supply chain to enable spare parts flow in the local market for sustainability of operation and maintenance of improved water sources will be very important to the sector; in 2022, UNICEF as part of its response, will explore opportunities for the development of supply chain for the local markets including use of voucher systems were feasible as well as strengthen human capacity at community level for operation and maintenance and sanitation market through WASH committees, private partnerships and hand pump mechanics associations.  In 2021 UNICEF trained 975 WASH committee members and 498 pump mechanics for sustainability of facilities.

IOM: IOM continued to invest in ensuring that communities themselves have the necessary skills to manage, operate, maintain and repair the water supply infrastructure built through its programs. In 2021, IOM trained 536 individuals as Water Management Committee members, as well as 101 Pump Mechanics, whilst promoting women's empowerment in such key WASH-related roles, ensuring that at least 50% were women.
2022 Narrative: For community water points, UNICEF supported training of 547 hand pump mechanics (382 males, 165 females) for newly established and rehabilitated boreholes aimed at strengthening operation and maintenance of the rural water systems and increasing functionality and sustainability of the water sources. The major objective of the training was to equip the community members with the basic skills on how to repair hand pump boreholes in the schools and at community level. After the training, they are equipped with tool kits for maintaining the boreholes with the objective that they will continue to improve the functionality of water supply sources through repair work. These trained community members played a vital role in supporting integration of WASH activities into nutrition and health programming for managing acute malnutrition in children under five years of age.

2024 Narrative: Through UNDP (Enviornment Unit), total of 20,014 families, of whom 11,038 (55%) were women and 8,976 (45%) men, benefited from access to drinking water, through the construction of 11 water boreholes equipped with photovoltaic energy system, with irrigation of around 200 to 700 meters, plus drinking troughs for animals, as well as horticulture in 11 communities.The SGP project significantly improved access to water in 11 communities by constructing boreholes powered by photovoltaic systems, enabling irrigation over areas of 200-700 meters, providing animal drinking troughs, and promoting horticulture. This initiative benefited 20,014 families, with women making up 55% of the recipients. Water usage in these communities now averages 176,000 to 230,000 liters per day.Under UNDP support, the Ministry of Environment and Biodiversity (MAB) completed aqueducts in Tebe and Uno with water control gates and a bridge to connect rice fields, benefiting 10,096 people (64% women). A 0.5-hectare forest nursery in Yemberem was also completed, along with a 19.5 km rural track in several communities, benefiting 1,834 people (48% women).

2021 Narrative:
UNICEF together with the national Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation annually rallied young people as agents of change in advocating for the role of hand washing in curbing disease transmission. This more so with the current COVID-19 pandemic that  has importantly highlighted the critical role hand hygiene plays in curbing disease transmission.  National and sub-national events are usually held targeting school going children all over South Sudan.

IOM: IOM carried out mass awareness campaigns to support national efforts around celebrating key global WASH-related days (WWD, WTD, WHD), as well as in supporting the national preparedness and response COVID-19 strategy. IOM was part of the Sanitation technical group provided support to MoWRI on the elaboration of the CLTS technical guidelines. IOM also contributed to the celebrations of International Women Day and 16 days of Activism, through its GBV Mainstreaming and Women's Empowerment approach in the WASH Sector. 

UNFPA:  Together with partners supported MHM day with advocacy activities and several initiatives to promote menstrual hygiene management
2022 Narrative: [10:51 PM] Jessica Kaku Joseph SullaIn 2022, Global Handwashing Day was celebrated in three schools in Central and Eastern Equatoria states, reaching over 1,500 people.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF supported and facilitated the coordination of the National ONE WASH coordination office and annual reporting of achievements is carried out regularly for the One WASH NP. UNICEF has supported the 11th Multi Stakeholders Forum on WASH, Water Resource Management and Energy was conducted in Addis Ababa under the theme of ‚ÄòAccelerated Implementation and Improved Impact Towards Achieving the SDGs‚Äô.UNICEF has supported MoWE to revitalize the Water and Energy Sectors Working Group (WSWG). UNICEF is the co-chair of the WSWG who jointly chairs with the State Minister of Water and Energy Ministry. The WSWG includes working groups in both water and sanitation, and it includes emergency and development WASH platforms with 4 sub-working groups of: a) Emergency WASH, b) Rural WASH, c) Urban WASH and d) Sanitation and Hygiene.UNICEF is also a Co-chair of Urban WASH TWG, a Co-chair Emergency WASH TWG, a Co-chair Hygiene  Sanitation TWG, a Chair WASH Cluster for 4 Region, and a Co-chair WASH Technical Committee for 4 Regions.UNICEF continued using the information management system as a tool for emergency cluster coordination, facilitated WASH emergency coordination at the national and regional levels, thereby avoided duplication of efforts and efficiently shared responsibilities among stakeholders during emergency response.Under the Resilient WASH (R-WASH) programme, UNICEF remained key partner in maintaining the coordination mechanism together with UNHCR and Refugees and Returnees Service (RRS). UNICEF WASH also leads high level sector advocacy such as WASH regulatory frameworks, policies and strategies.UNICEF has supported the involvement of the government of Ethiopia in the Sanitation and Water for All partnership, with active and strong participation in SWA meetings, the most recent a virtual High-Level Finance Ministers‚Äô Meeting for Africa, that took place on 31 October 2023. Besides, UNICEF supported two MoWE delegates to attend the 2023 Global Water and Health Conference organized by University of North Carolina from 22-27 October 2023, and experiences from Ethiopia was shared.With the support of UNICEF various trainings and capacity building interventions were carried out and WASH experts from federal, regional, and woreda WASH units have beneficiated in 2023.Moreover, UNICEF continued to support the system strengthening efforts of the MoWE, through development of regulatory framework and capacity development of water utilities.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: 2,948,702 people have gained access to basic sanitation services in rural areas and 1,560 communities are certified to be free from open defecation. As a result, about 8,936,000 people are living in open defecation free environments. Access to affordable durable sanitation products remains a challenge for the rural communities on account of affordability and access to financing. UNICEF continued support for smart subsidies to reach the most vulnerable population (those exempted from paying health insurance and those under the urban or rural productive safety net programme). In Addis Ababa sub-cities, WASH and Social Policy targeted selected households under the urban productive safety net programme to improve shared latrines by retrofitting SATO pans. These toilets are popular, and the users are proudly taking care of them. Four households share a toilet.A market-based sanitation approach is gaining ground, with undoubted demand for durable latrine products, but supply chain constraints are still an issue. Landed costs for imported sanitation products are beyond households without savings or micro-financing. Farming communities prefer seasonal lump sum payments. An evolving microfinancing approach addresses the needs of the middle pyramid population. Microfinancing models on the market in Ethiopia have demonstrated that farming households can repay microfinancing loans for durable toilet products in two lump sum payments including interest. UNICEF is developing partnerships for the microfinancing approach. This year, the support has been through supporting a scaling up of a model developed by FINISH Mondial consortium. The WASH Financing Strategy validation workshop registered interest from key stakeholders led by the Ministry of Finance to review and refine recommendation for enabling private financing to water, sanitation, and hygiene. Up to 15 Micro Finance Institutions (MFIs) are already lending to the water, sanitation, and hygiene sectors. Stakeholders have recommended government to consider a statutory proportion of loan financing for the sector as has for agriculture sector.  Some commercial banks are showing interest to consider or expand lending for water, sanitation, and hygiene. Some manufacturers have explored options for local manufacturing of their range of toilet products but are constrained with financial regulations and conditions for transfer of Molds. TSEDU National mobile application, targeting various groups such as religious leaders, HEWs, students, journalists, media practitioners, and the wider community is finalized. The app incorporates inclusive features like audio and sign language options for people with disabilities. Virtual Reality project utilizes virtual reality as a tool to educate school-age children about important WASH behaviors. The immersive experience offered by VR enhances learning and engagement, allowing children to interact with virtual scenarios and simulations. This creates a more impactful and memorable educational experience, effectively conveying key WASH practices such as hand hygiene, menstrual hygiene, improved toilet utilization, safe water management, and safe disposal of child faces. Add how many schools is this being tried in or add that it is finalized.

Sustaining peace marker: 1 - Contributes to sustaining peace empowerment in a limited way
2023 Narrative: More than 8,212,000 people are accessing sustainable drinking water along with 538 institutions that are provided with WASH services. 664 schools have institutionalized MHH services. Nearly 22 million people were reached with key hygiene messages on hygiene practices focusing on disease outbreaks to mitigate endemic Cholera and stop its spread.UNICEF played a vital role in strengthening the WASH system by supporting the development of inclusive interventions for SBC WASH programs. UNICEF supported the disability and gender inclusive national task force under the Ministry of Water to develop crucial national working documents like community feedback and response mechanisms, national SBC WASH school guidelines, MHH (Menstrual, Health and Hygiene)  in humanitarian settings, inclusive WASH guides, media practitioners‚Äô kits, and kits for religious leaders by providing both technical expertise and financial assistance.A comprehensive MHH program, was implemented in 664 schools. This program included activities such as establishing safe spaces, improving WASH facilities, providing MHH kits, and raising awareness and breaking taboos related to menstruation. As a result, a total of 88,920 adolescent girls and boys were reached and supported.UNICEF is a valued partner for regional government in the provision of climate resilient water supplies to rural communities. UNICEF supported the detailed design and construction of water supply schemes in Somali, Oromia, and Afar regions including continuation of the groundwater mapping and truthing drilling or selected boreholes. An extensive social and behavior change (SBC) WASH intervention was implemented to raise awareness and promote behavior change in key WASH practices targeting 14 Woredas across urban and rural areas. This intervention utilized various methods, including a radio program, campaigns, house-to-house visits, education, and community conversations. A total of 22,649,529 people were reached with hygiene promotion services in the prevention of disease.A comprehensive social and behavior change (SBC) WASH intervention for cholera prevention was implemented in the regions of Somalia, SNNP, and Oromia. This intervention reached over 5,246,000 individuals through a combination of radio broadcasts, audio van campaigns, community conversations, house-to-house visits, and the distribution of cholera materials.

2023 Narrative: UNICEF is transforming to Climate Resilient Urban WASH, and is working with partners on different initiatives, including solarization of water systems - to minimize reliance on the use of fossil fuels, thus offsetting carbon emissions, use of treated surface water for drinking (Gambela Town upgrading project) where groundwater resources are limited. UNICEF continued to invest in sustainable systems in urban and refugee areas and as a result 747,162 people were reached with water services, 518,308 people with sanitation services, and 824,486 people are reached with hygiene promotion during the reporting period with UNICEF direct support.Strengthening of urban utilities in 7 regions is conducted through different approaches including the Water Operators Partnership (WOP) approach, wherein UNICEF has developed partnership with Global Water Operators' Partnerships Alliance (GWOPA), and international utilities to work as mentors for the Ethiopian utilities. Moreover, UNICEF has signed an MOU with the ‚ÄúEthiopian Urban Water and Sewage Federation‚Äù to scale up the system strengthen approaches to all the remaining 925 utilities.Transitional process from NGOs led Operations and Maintenance of water systems led to utilities with enhanced capacities (Kebrebeyah, Aw Barre, Sheder ‚Äì Somali Region) to ensure sustainability.Under the Resilient WASH (R- WASH) project, which is a climate-smart initiative, UNICEF remained instrumental in strengthening the coordination mechanism with support from MoWE, UNHCR, BMZ, KFW, NL embassy, urban utilities and other sector partners and with partners in Somalia and Sudan. This has resulted in implementation of the inclusion policy, to build and strengthen the existing water utilities capacity to improve the reliability of the supply of water for the host communities and the displaced populations of refugees and IDPs.Strengthening of Climate Resilient Systems and Capacity is ongoing in nine town water utility systems, with the support of FCDO. Diagnostic assessments of systems and capacity of 18 TWUs are completed. In addition, development of utility business plans have been completed for all the 18 TWUs and implementation of targeted utility systems and capacity development interventions are ongoing in all except the three Amhara towns due to the ongoing conflict. In total, 17 senior experts were seconded to MoWE and the four-climate resilient WASH programme regions.After source development in Bidre (Oromia region) and Bule and Doyo Gena (SNNP region) is completed, contracts are signed for civil works construction and supply and installation of pipes and fittings, construction sites are handed over and construction work is commenced in all the three towns.

2023 Narrative: In Somalia, a groundbreaking achievement has been made with the introduction of the first-ever MSc program on Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM). In collaboration with the Somalia National University (SNU) and the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources (MoEWR), UNDP Somalia has addressed the country's water resource management challenges by enrolling 35 students (27 males and 8 females) who will become skilled professionals in managing water resources sustainably. Efforts have also been dedicated to enhancing the understanding and capabilities of individuals and institutions in Galmudug State, Somalia, regarding IWRM. This initiative involves 65 officials (45 males and 20 females) and provides both foundational and advanced knowledge and skills necessary for the successful implementation of the IWRM program in the country. Additionally, the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources (MoEWR) has played a pivotal role in promoting water management coordination through localized meetings focused on IWRM Institutional Coordination and Leadership Engagement. These efforts have significantly improved the overall effectiveness of water resource management initiatives in Somalia, establishing a more coordinated approach and driving sustainable development in the country.
2024 Narrative: ‚Ä¢ Increased Academic Expertise in IWRM: Thirty-four graduates, including eight women, successfully completed the MSc program in Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM), focusing on sustainable water use, climate change impacts, water governance, and socioeconomic dimensions, empowering graduates to address Somalia‚Äôs pressing water challenges effectively‚Ä¢ Enhanced Institutional Coordination: The Ministry of Energy and Water Resources (MoEWR) strengthened strategic coordination and leadership, aligning federal and state-level efforts to achieve sustainable water resource management in Somalia.‚Ä¢ Research Impact and Career Development: Contributed to advancing national and global water resource management by publishing 34 research papers, enriching the knowledge base and informing policy and practice. Facilitated graduate employment opportunities by organizing a career fair that connected government, private sector, and academic institutions, fostering collaboration and professional pathways.

2024 Narrative: In total, 456,566 individuals (334,214 females, 122,352 males, and 4,566 persons with special needs) have been reached with coordinated ES/NFI assistance.To date, the CCCM Cluster has developed 12 high-quality informational products to highlight partner achievements and bolster advocacy at national and regional levels. two rounds of Site Assessment and two rounds of Village Assessment Survey were conducted. (ES/NFI) Cluster strengthened preparedness and technical capacity to undertake interventions to humanitarian emergencies with clear leadership and accountability while addressing shelter and NFI needs of affected populations. the RRF with implementing partners delivered 9,890 emergency shelter kits, and 9,890 NFI kits for displaced households outside of the northern response. IOM registered 1,500 newly displaced households to receive NFI kits. The project areas are Tigray, Amhara, Afar Benishangul Gumz, Oromia, Somali, Gambella, SNNP and South West regions of Ethiopia.

2023 Narrative: In the Gawan Hobyo area, the local authorities allocated 81 hectares of land to construct 12 soil bunds totalling 9,210 meters. The soil bunds constructed the contour lines, enabling them to deter the overland flow and prevent not only gully formations but also allow the excess water to infiltrate the soil, promoting vegetation growth in the area sandwiched by the contours. With the rainy season, the maize and cowpeas have already started growing, providing adaptation opportunities for the clusters of villages in the Gawan area.

2023 Narrative: Women-led diplomacy groups were formed in Bilcil, Hobyo, Duqaqo, Buqaloc and Qoroyoweyne, comprising of 5 women per group and a total of 35 across Galmudug. 8 water user committees were established, consisting of 5 community members (4 male and 1 Female). A phased approach was used to provide water user committee training closer to the time of handover of the water facilities created by the project. The number of people actively participating in natural resource management committees increased by 10% in the above target locations.

UNHCR

2022 Narrative: The UN supported baseline for Climate, Environment and Energy emphasizing strengthening WASH climate financing and encourage contributions for the delivery of a climate change-sensitive approach. The UN supported MoWE to develop a national climate rationale and results framework for WASH, strengthen the WASH climate financing and influenced adaptation of more resilient WASH interventions and linkage to climate change.The UN support to government enabled the finalization of the national WASH in health care facilities guidelines, providing evidence on SDG status and required cost of investment to close the gap. With UN support 110,400 people out of the annual target of 125,000 people were provided with water services through emergency interventions. 14 percent of the annual target of 35,000 people have received sanitation services through emergency interventions. A total of 769,400 people were reached with critical WASH supplies out of the annual target of 280,000 people. UN support in 2022 focused on supporting operation and maintenance of over 207 motorized water systems (95 per cent hybrid powered, 29.4Mega Watt of solar power in use) and 1,037 hands pump, and establishment of 12 new water sources. As a result, water was supplied at an average of 17 litres per capita.UN support saw a reduction in latrine coverage in affected population from 72 percent in 2021 to 68 percent in 2022, despite construction of over 8,000 new latrines for refugee and national hosting population. This is due to increased new arrivals and flood episodes that dilapidated many latrines,. IOM3 permanent handwashing facilities were constructed at 3 Points of Entry; Elegu, Mutukula and Kasensero. This was to promote culture of hand washing inorder to prevent disease spread at border points.2 Cross-border coordination meetings were held at EAC-regional level, between Uganda and Tanzania in order to discuss border health.A total of 352 community influencers/key informants and 141,190 community members were reached through 33 community led awareness and sensitization sessions conducted with messages on disease prevention, water, sanitation and hygiene at border pointsA total of 6,040 IEC materials with information on prevention of covid-19 and other communicable disease were printed and distributed
2023 Narrative: UNHCRAchievements: In WASH Sector, UNCT and the partners have continued to ensure the provision of 23,272 m3 total water supplied daily in all 13 refugee settlements across Uganda. The consumption per person per day has been 17 liters during the reporting period. The partners have continued to ensure a gender inclusive and equitable access to safe water, sanitation and hygiene facilities and have maintained a 66% sanitation coverage. The ratio of hygiene promoters is 1:522.UNICEFThe UNICFE WASH Programme supported MWE to train District Water Officers from 145 districts in data collection and analysis for the SDG monitoring framework, focusing on SDG 6.1 indicators. The knowledge acquired by district personnel will ensure effective guidance to the district leaders and ASPs in the roll out of the revised OM framework.The UNICFE WASH Programme supported MWE to train District Water Officers from 145 districts in data collection and analysis for the SDG monitoring framework, focusing on SDG 6.1 indicators. The knowledge acquired by district personnel will ensure effective guidance to the district leaders and ASPs in the roll out of the revised OM framework.In 2020, the Ministry of Water and Environment (MWE) received support to review the operationalization of the national Operation and Maintenance (OM) framework. The review aimed at enhancing the formation of community structures, identification of Area Service Providers (ASPs), and assessing district authorities' achievements in implementing the OM framework efficiently. Concurrently, UNICEF, in collaboration with Water Missions, installed 10 remote sensing data loggers in Karamoja as part of climate resilience efforts. These loggers offer real-time data on static and dynamic water levels to monitor aquifer sustainability and water system functionality.The Ministry of Health (MoH) received assistance in developing a new National Sanitation Policy, involving stakeholder engagement and a Regulatory Impact Assessment (RIA). Additionally, support was extended to MoH for creating manuals on case management and responding to waterborne disease outbreaks.UNICEF's interventions led to 123,293 people gaining access to basic sanitation services. Market-Based Sanitation initiatives were implemented to stimulate the private sector, generate demand for sanitation services, and enhance district capacities. In institutional Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH), 48 schools (against a target of 45) and 9 health centers received appropriate facilities.Under Emergency WASH, UNICEF responded to public health crises, including Ebola, Marburg, Cholera outbreaks, flooding, and droughts. Approximately 64,900 people in humanitarian situations received safe water, and 702,479 individuals were provided with critical WASH supplies, focusing on institutions. Additionally, 11,004 people in institutions received support with emergency latrines.

Increased water access led to higher school enrolment in once water-scarce areas. Newly built dams now provide vital irrigation, enhancing crop production, supporting afforestation/reforestation, and rehabilitating rangelands. Villagers grow fresh vegetables, improving diets and creating new business opportunities. Also, UNDP‚Äôs initiatives to improve rangeland productivity and water and fodder availability have strengthened community resilience. Capacity-building for engineers, technicians, and community resource persons in data collection, treatment, and analysis has enhanced Somalia's ability to monitor and manage climate risk

Sub-Output: Strengthen HWC management by upgrading data systems, training staff, equipping regional units, and implementing mitigation measures, including predator-proof kraals and elephant-friendly water points. Strengthen field operations through research, technology, and capacity building to improve conflict response and community resilience across NW, NC, and NE hotspot landscapes.
Description:
Strengthen HWC management by upgrading and maintaining the national HWC database, developing policy SOPs, and training staff through specialized IT, IS, and HWC short courses. Equip and operationalize regional HWC management units with essential resources, including uniforms and equipments. Implement targeted capacity-building programs for MEFT staff, conservancy members, game guards, and lion rangers to enhance conflict response and mitigation strategies. Support community conservancies with educational materials and continuous outreach through print, electronic, and digital media.

Implement key infrastructure and technology-based mitigation measures to reduce human-wildlife conflict in hotspot landscapes. Upgrade and install water infrastructure, predator-proof kraals, and elephant-proof enclosures to safeguard communities and resources. Deploy satellite collars and GPS transmitters on selected predators to enhance monitoring and research. Contract HWC research organizations to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of alternative mitigation measures, ensuring evidence-based interventions.
Implementation partners: Namibia Ministry of Environment, Forestry and Tourism
SDG Targets: 15.7 Take urgent action to end poaching and trafficking of protected species of flora and fauna and address both demand and supply of illegal wildlife products.
Geography: Kavango East; Kunene; Zambezi; Oshikoto; Omusati; Namibia
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Suboutput also contributes to the follow: 3.2 Strengthened capacities of institutions and marginalized communities for climate change resilience and disaster risk reduction.

2022 Narrative: The establishment of home gardens did not involve the clearing of forestland nor the use of agrochemicals, but rather encouraged and promoted the use of composted manure and animal droppings.Food demonstrations and recipe development used energy sources that did not generate any greenhouse gas emissions that might pollute the atmosphere.The project encouraged the use of cost-effective technologies utilizing locally accessible materials, such as discarded car tires, empty containers, and wooden boxes, to establish home gardens for the production of nutrient-rich food.

Plan name: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANCE FRAMEWORK (UNDAF) 2018-2022
Outcome: Outcome 2.8 -  By 2022, individuals and communities in Kenya have reduced exposure to risks and are more resilient to disasters and emergencies.
Output: Output 2.8.2 - 2.7.2:  Capacity of Cities and Human Settlements  as drivers of sustainable urbanization, economic growth and social transformation is strengthened
Sub-Output: Support to urban waterfront planning and development within the Coastal Cities
Description: Support to urban waterfront planning and development is anchored in the 4-year (2021 ‚Äì 2024) Go Blue project being implemented jointly with UNEP and Jumuiya ya Kaunti za Pwani (JKP) in six Coastal Counties of Kilifi, Kwale, Mombasa, Taita Taveta, Tana River and Lamu. The supports the implementation of the Declaration of the Blue Economy Conference hosted by Kenya in 2018. Its objective is to build capacity of institutions and relevant staff in land ‚Äì sea planning and management for maximum benefits from the blue economy. The project will build information hubs, promote evidenced based spatial planning, demonstrate interventions protecting ecosystems such as sustainable wastewater and solid waste management, protection of mangroves, as well as developing infrastructure that facilitate access to the benefits from the blue economy such as tourism (public open spaces e.g. beaches), fish landing sites etc while creating jobs for women and the youths. The project was launched on 25 March 2021, inception activities have commenced, and project officers reassigned to support project implementation.
SDG Targets: 11.3 By 2030, enhance inclusive and sustainable urbanization and capacity for participatory, integrated and sustainable human settlement planning and management in all countries.,11.6 By 2030, reduce the adverse per capita environmental impact of cities, including by paying special attention to air quality and municipal and other waste management.,11.a Support positive economic, social and environmental links between urban, peri-urban and rural areas by strengthening national and regional development planning.
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
2021 Narrative: This project is just on its initial stage of implementation of activities. So far only the baseline survey has been carried out to inform the current status of urban planning in the six counties of Kwale, Mombasa, Lamu, Kilifi, Taita Taveta, and Tana River Counties. It is part of the Go Blue project which is a Joint project being implemented by the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat) and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP). The aim is to support the development of a sustainable Blue Economy in Kenya by contributing to the economic development for coastal urban citizens and the protection of coastal and marine assets. The project‚Äôs overall objective is to ensure an integrated, ecosystem-based approach to land-sea planning and management in a participatory and inclusive manner, especially for women and young people, resulting into enhanced capacity of institutions and citizens for land-sea planning and management for climate change adaptation and mitigation in the coastal urban areas. The implementation of the project is being carried out in coordination with the Coastal Counties Economic Bloc (JKP) and is being implemented in six Coastal Counties of Mombasa, Kwale, Kilifi, Tana River, Taita Taveta, and Lamu. The project has a 4 years timelines of implementation i.e. 2021 - 2024.

Description: Neighborhood plan that is guiding the regeneration of the lake front stimulated by the resuscitation of the port attracting investment by the private sector was prepared in 2014. The City of Kisumu‚Äôs ‚ÄúIntegrated Strategic Urban Development (ISUD) Plan‚Äù, identified the Lakefront Area as a key asset for the city and proposed its development as an extension of the Central Business District (CBD). Objectives: Plan the land to  a) benefit the city; b) present economic gains for land owners and developers; and c) preserve the local economy that was active in part of the area. UN-Habitat prepared the Lakefront Development Advisory Plan and further analyzed legislation and overall economic feasibility of the areas. UN-Habitat also proposed the formation of Lakefront Development Corporation, a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) that would promote private sector investment and development of the lakefront. The Governor has so far established the SPV.

In particular, through this intervention IOM will facilitate the construction of sustainable and durable infrastructures for water supply and sanitation designed to be appropriate and scalable for future upgrades and inclusive for people with disabilities. The programme establishes WASH committees to ensure ownership, proper operation and maintenance of the WASH infrastructures. Simultaneously, IOM will deliver hygiene promotion activities to support the prevention of water-related diseases and to ensure a healthy personal hygiene that contributes to the well-being of the communities. Hygiene promotion is done through different modalities, household visits, leisure activities, hygiene kits distribution and the possibility, when appropriate, of cash-based interventions to acquire hygiene items. Furthermore, to ensure sustainability and using our WASH local and global expertise, the programme strives to increase the response of the national and local government water and sanitation departments through capacity building activities. Overall, IOM attempts to provide a comprehensive WASH package in selected IDP sites and host communities in coordination with CCCM and other IOM‚Äôs units, following a multi-sector response approach, which can improve in general the availability of services. The Slovenia contribution will contribute to push the programme forward in Mozambique and to attend emergency needs through the rehabilitation of water points, construction of latrines for PwD and distribution of emergency hygiene kits for new displacement.
Implementation partners: Government of Mozambique
SDG Targets: 6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.
