2022 Narrative: In 2022, UNICEF Mozambique continued positioning itself as a key partner for the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Education to further strengthen enabling environment for implementation of WASH in healthcare facilities (HCFs) and schools‚Äô programmes. Only in 2022, 23 healthcare facilities (121 per cent of the planned target) received a water, sanitation, waste management and hygiene services full package resulting in improved health services for at least 16,000 maternity inpatients. Likewise, 109 schools (206 per cent of the planned target) received a similar WASH infrastructures and hygiene promotion package benefitting at least 53,259 children with improved learning conditions.ÔªøWASH in institutions was created as a standalone output under the new CPD 2022-2026 to increase the visibility of the dire situation of water, sanitation, and hygiene in institutions, particularly in HCFs and schools. UNICEF Mozambique built on the experience and lessons learnt consolidated in previous years, as well as on UNICEF‚Äôs leadership role in Education, Health and Nutrition sectors, to continue positioning itself as a key partner for the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Education to further strengthen enabling environment for implementation of WASH in HCFs and schools‚Äô programmes. In 2022, a total of 23 HCF, 4 of them in humanitarian contexts, received a full package of WASH infrastructures (solar powered water supply system, gender disaggregated and inclusive toilets, solid waste management system and kitchen/laundry blocks) which represents 121 per cent of the planned targets. This over-achievement was related to emergency intervention not included in initial planning. These interventions benefitted at least 16,000 mothers hospitalized in maternity wards (source: National Health Information System ‚Äì SISMA). On top of it, detailed designs and tender documents have been developed for 50 HCFs in Zambezia, Nampula and Niassa provinces. Since sustainability continue to be a major problem in this area, UNICEF Mozambique further supported capacity building activities and trained 129 health workers, from 30 facilities in Zambezia and Nampula provinces, to better operate and maintain WASH infrastructures and conduct hygiene promotion activities. In coordination with the MoH, UNICEF continued supporting the roll out of the WASH-FIT trainings (Facility Improvement Tool), a tool created to ensure regular evaluation and improvement of infectious diseases prevention and control in HCFs. This support is included in the roadmap developed by the WASH in HCFs multi-sectoral group to further strengthen enabling environment to achieve full WASH coverage in HCFs by 2030. Progresses in this area have been constrained by the limited capacity and competing priorities of MoH staff, as well as for lack of data for planning. At school level, 109 schools (206 per cent of the planned target) gained access to an improved water source, among which 20 got access to a full WASH package including basic sanitation and hygiene services. This translated into around 53,259 additional school children (25,610 girls and 27,649 boys) having access to at least basic water services at school. This over-achievement was related to increased awareness of communities about the importance of WASH in schools, particularly after COVID-19, triggering their decision of locating water points in neighboring schools, rather than in the communities.  As sustainability is also a major problem for schools, UNICEF Mozambique supported the establishment and training of water committees to manage water sources, with strong accent on gender balance. Menstrual hygiene management was also mainstreamed in all WASH in Schools interventions with a training package being delivered through school councils and PEC contractors as well as by ensuring that infrastructures built ensure the minimum required privacy.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, 46 out of the 51 targeted HCFs, representing an achievement of 90%, benefited from a full WASH package that includes solar system providing running water at critical points of the health care facility, gender separated and inclusive toilets, as well as solid waste management systems. At least 36,000 maternity inpatients benefitted from these improved services and infrastructures (SISMA, 2023). In parallel, technical assessments and designs were developed for 89 HCFs and construction contracts were signed for 60 HCFs in 3 provinces. As part of capacity building activities, UNICEF trained 65 health workers and on operation, maintenance and an additional 88 health workers on WASHFIT. At school level, 71 schools located in rural areas, where the most needs are, gained access to improved water sources, representing an achievement of 103% of the annual target and translating into 42,600 additional school children reached and benefiting from a more conducive learning environment (19,170 girls and 23,430 boys). Out of these, 41 schools received a full WASH package, while 30 schools benefitted only from improved water services. Beyond infrastructures construction, UNICEF provided technical and financial support in all target schools to the establishment or revitalization of water committees which were trained on operation and maintenance. A strong gender lens was applied to all WASH interventions at school level, including a focus on menstrual hygiene management. In this area, an innovative approach, proposing a combination of awareness raising activities and distribution of reusable pads to schoolgirls, was developed in urban areas. As a result, a total of 1,300 schoolgirls received hygiene kits and 6,109 school children (3,057 boys and 3,052 girls) received information on menstruation to break myths and taboos. Learnings are being generated for use into future WinS Interventions.UNICEF also worked at upstream level to strengthen the enabling environment for WASH in Institutions. UNICEF used its convening power to support the development of a national advocacy agenda on WASH in HCFs and the establishment of sub-working groups led by the MoH. These sub-groups are supporting the finalization and approval of norms and standards for WASH in HCFs, as well as the creation of an effective operation and maintenance monitoring system. In this regard, steady progresses were made for the roll out of the WASHFIT tool, including the translation of the WASHFIT manual and training package into Portuguese, the establishment of an accreditation system certifying HCFs implementing WASHFIT, as well as the identification and empowerment of a national institution to deliver WASHFIT courses. For WASH in Schools, UNICEF continued supporting the Ministry of Education on the development of norms and standards for WASH in schools through an inclusive and nationwide consultation that will lead to more harmonized WASH support at school level among partners.

Plan name: United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2022-2026
Outcome: Outcome 1: By 2026, more people, particularly the most vulnerable and marginalized, have a more equitable access to and utilization of quality, inclusive, resilient, gender- and shock-responsive social protection and essential social services.
Output: Output 1.2: Vulnerable and marginalized people are empowered to access and utilize essential social services and protection systems they need, across the life course
Sub-Output: In humanitarian contexts, every child, including adolescents receive timely and adequate assistance in water, sanitation, and hygiene and communities are better prepared to resist to shocks.
Description: Water, sanitation and hygiene systems and empowerment of communities; Climate change, disaster risks and environmental degradation; Safe and equitable water, sanitation and hygiene services and practices.
Contributing partners: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention USA; European Commission; European Commission Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations; Global Thematic - Humanitarian Response; Government of Canada; Government of Ireland; Government of Italy; Government of Norway; Government of Switzerland; Government of the Netherlands; Government of the United Kingdom; Kreditanstalt f√ºr Wiederaufbau - KfW Development Bank; Swedish International Development Agency; UNITED NATIONS JOINT PROGRAMME; United Nations Children's Fund; United Nations Office for Project Services; United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs; United States Agency for International Development Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance
Implementation partners: HelpCode; Helvetas Swiss Intercooperation; ISTITUTO OIKOS; Mozambique Provincial Directorate of Public Work, Housing and Water Resources CABO DELGADO; Solidarites International
SDG Targets: 6.1 By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.,6.2 By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.,6.3 By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.,6.4 By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.
Geography: Zambezia; Nampula; Cabo Delgado; Sofala; Mozambique
Gender marker: 2 - Gender equality/women's empowerment is a significant objective
Gender marker narrative: Output is expected to make a significant contribution to advancing gender equality and / or empowerment of girls and women.
Human rights marker: 2 - Significant contribution to realization of human rights
Focal users: Alwin Nijholt; Narcya Manjate Chilengue; Salesio  Missomal
2022 Narrative: In 2022, UNICEF Mozambique and its partners managed to timely respond to all the emergencies affecting the country and make important progresses in most indicators, despite a funding gap of more than 60% per cent of the fund requirements included in the HAC 2022. The only indicator that did not progress is the one related to disaster risk reduction given lack of funds for this activity, a situation that is now partially addressed and is expected to progress in 2023. Cabo Delgado conflict further deteriorated in the last months of 2022 with new Non-State Armed Group (NSAG) attacks resulting in new displacements - 940,000 Internally Displace Population (IDP)s (Displacement tracking Monitoring (DTM). Nov 2022) - that affected Cabo Delgado, Nampula and Niassa provinces. In this context only, UNICEF provided appropriate drinking water services to 251,815 people (60,337 with durable solutions). Water trucking was mainly used to supply water to at least 100,000IDPs living in temporary or resettlements sites where durable solutions were not feasible, or during construction works.99,018 people where reached with sanitation and hygiene services provided by UNICEF‚Äôs implementing partners, 85,730 of them with durable solutions. Temporary solutions were mainly used in temporary sites where at least 30 communal latrines were built and regularly dislodged by local services providers that ensured proper collection, transport, and disposal. In resettlement sites and host communities, UNICEF promoted the CLTS approach adapted to emergency context while, for more vulnerable households, UNICEF‚Äôs partners continued distributing slabs. Disability was mainstreamed with disability add-on products procured via UNICEF Supply Division‚Äôs and distributed to vulnerable people. Through at least 13 Joint Rapid Response, in coordination with WFP and IOM, a total of 186,935 people received critical WASH supplies. In less than 30 days (February ‚Äì March 2022), Mozambique was hit by two significant weather events - Tropical Storm Ana and Tropical Cyclone Gombe - affecting the same provinces: Nampula, Zambezia and Tete. In response to damages caused by these natural disasters, UNICEF quickly organized a response that included the rehabilitation of 95 boreholes equipped with handpumps,4 water supply systems (3 of them solar-powered) benefitting 52,079 people, distribution of critical WASH supplies, including hygiene kits and water purification items for 68,740 people. Cholera outbreaks were reported in 2022 in 4 districts of the provinces of Sofala, Zambezia and Niassa. UNICEF partnered with NGOs and provincial authorities to contain these outbreaks using Case Area Targeted Intervention (CATI) approach. Transmission-reducing interventions included active case-finding and referral to cholera treatment centers, as well as household-level WASH measures. In response to 1 Polio case confirmed in Tete province, UNICEF Mozambique quickly deployed a response using the same CATI approach resulting in 7 rehabilitated boreholes and the affected community certified as ODF. UNICEF Mozambique supported updating contingency plans in risk-prone provinces, as well as replenishment of contingency stocks as part of disaster preparedness activities for 2023 cyclone season. Five contingency partnerships were signed and activated at least 7 times during the year. Disaster risk reduction interventions are planned to 2023.
2023 Narrative: In 2023, UNICEF responded to several humanitarian crisis, including those originated by armed conflicts, but also by natural disasters and public health emergencies. Although humanitarian WASH indicators did not meet the revised HAC targets, mainly due to a funding gap of around 85%, absolute numbers of beneficiaries for water supply increased 2.8 times; for sanitation, 4.6 times, and WASH supplies 5.5 times in comparison to 2022, which gives an indication of the huge scale and scope of the response. In total, 1,253,404 people were reached with appropriate drinking water services (51% of HAC target), of which 18% with durable solutions. 552,543 people were reached with appropriate sanitation (32% HAC target), of which about 68% gained basic and durable sanitation. Substantial WASH supplies were delivered benefitting 1,398,825 (109% of HAC target), including support to 73,363 women and girls with menstrual hygiene management materials. Additionally, 62 health care facilities were also supported with WASH Supplies.The conflict in Cabo Delgado, although lose some intensity, continued triggering displacement and, as of August 2023, around 627,846 people remained displaced, while 540,958 had returned to their homes. The sudden movements of people intensified pressure on the already limited WASH services. Only in this context, UNICEF and its partners provided emergency water supply to 127,400 IDP in temporary and resettlement sites through water trucking. Additionally, safe drinking water services was provided for 97,408 people, through durable solutions including construction and rehabilitation of water points and water networks. Appropriate sanitation was provided to 107,139 people using a mix of approaches including construction of emergency latrines, traditional latrines through provision of slabs and technical assistance.During the first quarter of 2023, Mozambique was affected by heavy rains that provoked floods in several locations and the tropical Cyclone Freddy that made landfall two times in central region. At least 184,000 people were forced to displace, and infrastructures and services, including water and sanitation, suffered huge damages. Simultaneously, a cholera outbreak, declared in September 2022 in Niassa province, expand to the whole country, affecting all 11 provinces and 76 out of the 161 districts, with 37,000 cases and 151 deaths (CFR - 0.4%), reported as of September 2023. A new counting then started on October 1st and, as of December 18th, 6,703 cases and 14 deaths, (CFR - 0.2%) had been reported in 25 districts. In this context, UNICEF deployed a massive emergency response that resulted in, 1,253,404 people being reached with appropriate drinking water services, of which 18% with durable solutions, most of them (95%) in rural areas. In total 586 water points were constructed or rehabilitated using the ‚ÄúBuilding back better‚Äù approach to ensure resilience. Additionally, 552,543 people were reached with appropriate sanitation services. Building on this experience, UNICEF further enhance its preparedness by training critical staff from the government, civil society and private sector on WASH in Emergency in all provinces and pre-positioning WASH critical supplies in UNICEF, but also partners, warehouses. A disaster risk reduction pilot project was also launched in Sofala province.
